1.title: Chapter 1: Introduction
1.prose_html:
Opening: The Transmission of the Teaching

Thus have I heard.¹ At one time, the Buddha was dwelling at Mount Gṛdhrakūṭa near the city of Rājagṛha,² together with a great assembly of twelve thousand bhikṣus.³ All of these practitioners had attained the state of Arhat—having exhausted all outflows of mental affliction, having eliminated all defilements, having realized their own ultimate benefit, having severed all bonds of conditioned existence, and having attained complete freedom of mind.⁴

Their names are recorded as follows: Ājñātakauṇḍinya, Mahākāśyapa, Uruvilvākāśyapa, Gayākāśyapa, Nadīkāśyapa, Śāriputra, Mahāmaudgalyāyana, Mahākātyāyana, Aniruddha, Kapphiṇa, Gavāṃpati, Revata, Pilindavatsa, Bakkula, Mahākauṣṭhila, Nanda, Sundarananda, Pūrṇamaitrāyaṇīputra, Subhūti, Ānanda, and Rāhula—great Arhats of this caliber, well known throughout all communities of practitioners.⁵

---

The Assembly: All Beings Present

Furthermore, there were also two thousand persons⁶ among both those still in training and those who had completed their training. The bhikṣuṇī Mahāprajāpatī was present together with her retinue of six thousand bhikṣuṇīs.⁷ Yaśodharā, the mother of Rāhula, was also present with her retinue.⁸

Additionally, there were eighty thousand Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas,⁹ all of whom had become irreversible in their aspiration toward the attainment of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi (supreme perfect enlightenment).¹⁰ All had attained the dharaṇī¹¹—the power to retain and preserve teaching—and possessed eloquence in joyful exposition. They had already turned the irreversible Dharma wheel,¹² spreading teachings that cannot be reversed or overturned.

These Bodhisattvas had made offerings to innumerable hundreds of thousands of Buddhas, and in the presence of all these Buddhas they had planted deep roots of virtue. They were constantly praised by all Buddhas on account of their devotion and accomplishment. They cultivated themselves through the mind of compassion (maitrī and karuṇā), skillfully entered into Buddha-wisdom,¹³ thoroughly penetrated the great wisdom of ultimate reality,¹⁴ and thereby reached the farther shore—transcending the realm of conditioned existence.¹⁵

Their fame was universally heard throughout immeasurable worlds, and they possessed the power to liberate innumerable hundreds of thousands of living beings. Their names are recorded as: the Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī (He of Transcendent Wisdom),¹⁶ the Bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara (the One Who Observes the Sounds of the World),¹⁷ the Bodhisattva Mahāsthāmaprāpta, the Bodhisattva Nityodyukta (Ever-Exerting), the Bodhisattva Aniksiptadhura, the Bodhisattva Ratnapāṇi (He with the Jeweled Hand), the Bodhisattva Medicine King, the Bodhisattva Pradānaśūra (Courageous in Giving), the Bodhisattva Ratnacandra (Jeweled Moon), the Bodhisattva Candraprabha (Moonlight), the Bodhisattva Pūrṇacandra (Full Moon), the Bodhisattva Mahāvikramin (Great Strider), the Bodhisattva Anantavikramin (Boundless Strider), the Bodhisattva Trailokyavikrama (Strider Through the Three Realms), the Bodhisattva Bhadrapāla (Excellent Guardian), the Bodhisattva Maitreya (He of Loving-Kindness), the Bodhisattva Ratnākara (Ocean of Jewels), and the Bodhisattva Susārthavāha (Bearing Meaningful Gifts)—eighty thousand Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas of this caliber were all present in the assembly.¹⁸

---

The Celestial and Divine Attendants

Moreover, Śakra Devānām Indra (the Lord of the Thirty-Three Heavens) was present with his retinue of twenty thousand celestial sons.¹⁹ The celestial sons Candravimala (Moonlight), Manojñasvara, Ratnacchattra, and the Four Great Heavenly Kings were also present, together with their retinue of ten thousand celestial sons.²⁰

The celestial sovereigns Īśvara and Maheśvara were present with their retinue of thirty thousand celestial sons. The Brahmā Heavenly King—the lord of the Sahā world (our cosmic realm)—together with Śikhin Mahābrahman, Jyotiṣprabha Mahābrahman, and others, were present with their retinue of twelve thousand celestial sons.²¹

There were eight Dragon Kings: the Dragon King Nanda, the Dragon King Upananda, the Dragon King Sāgara, the Dragon King Vāsukin, the Dragon King Takṣaka, the Dragon King Anavatapta, the Dragon King Manasvin, and the Dragon King Utpalaka—each accompanied by several hundreds of thousands of retinue members.²²

There were four Kiṃnara Kings: the Kiṃnara King Dharma, the Kiṃnara King Sudharma, the Kiṃnara King Mahādharma, and the Kiṃnara King Dharmadhara—each with several hundreds of thousands of attendants.

There were four Gandharva Kings: the Gandharva King Manojña, the Gandharva King Manojñasvara, the Gandharva King Madhura, and the Gandharva King Madhurasvara—each with several hundreds of thousands of retinue members.

There were four Asura Kings: the Asura King Balin, the Asura King Kharaskandha, the Asura King Vemacitra, and the Asura King Rāhu—each with several hundreds of thousands of attendants.

There were four Garuḍa Kings: the Garuḍa King Mahātejas (Great Radiance), the Garuḍa King Mahākāya (Great Form), the Garuḍa King Mahāpūrṇa (Great Fullness), and the Garuḍa King Manojña (Pleasing to Mind)—each with several hundreds of thousands of retinue members.

King Ajātaśatru, son of Vaidehī, was present with several hundreds of thousands of retinue members.²³ All in the assembly bowed respectfully at the Buddha's feet and withdrew to sit respectfully to one side.²⁴

---

The Buddha's Teaching and Cosmic Manifestation

At that time, the World-Honored One, surrounded by the fourfold assembly²⁵ and having been honored with reverent offerings, praise, and adoration, expounded for the assembled Bodhisattvas a Mahāyāna sutra entitled the Sutra of Immeasurable Meanings—a teaching for Bodhisattvas, treasured and protected by the Buddhas.²⁶

Having concluded his exposition of this sutra, the Buddha sat in full lotus posture (padmāsana)²⁷ and entered into the samādhi of the abode of immeasurable meanings²⁸—a meditative absorption in which his body and mind remained utterly still and unmoved, entering a state of unified, non-dualistic awareness.²⁹

Thereupon heavenly mandārava flowers, great mandārava flowers, mañjūṣaka flowers, and great mañjūṣaka flowers rained down abundantly from the heavens, scattering upon the Buddha and upon the great assembly.³⁰ The entire Buddha-world quaked and trembled in six ways—a cosmic manifestation signifying the profound nature of the teaching being conveyed.³¹

---

The Universal Response

At that time, all the beings present in the assembly—bhikṣus, bhikṣuṇīs, upāsakas (male lay practitioners), upāsikās (female lay practitioners), devas (celestial beings), nāgas (serpent-beings), yakṣas (nature spirits), gandharvas (celestial musicians), asuras (anti-gods), garuḍas (divine eagles), kiṃnaras (celestial musicians), mahoragas (great serpents), humans, and non-human beings, together with the lesser kings and wheel-turning sage kings³²—the entire great assembly experienced phenomena they had never before experienced.

Filled with joy, they placed their palms together in salutation and gazed upon the Buddha with unified attention, their minds focused single-pointedly.³³

---

The Buddha's Light and the Revelation of Other Worlds

At that time, the Buddha emitted a ray of light from the tuft of white hair between his eyebrows (the ūrṇā-keśa, an auspicious mark of Buddhahood).³⁴ This light illuminated eighteen thousand worlds to the east, omitting none, extending downward to the Avīci hell³⁵ and upward to the Akaniṣṭha Heaven (the highest heaven of the form realm).³⁶

Within this illumination, from the perspective of our world, the beings of the six paths of rebirth³⁷ in all those lands were completely visible. The six destinies of sentient existence—beings born in hell, as hungry ghosts, as animals, as asuras, as humans, and as celestial beings—each in their respective realms, appeared as if in direct vision.

Moreover, the Buddhas presently dwelling in those eighteen thousand worlds to the east were seen, and the sutras and Dharma teachings that those Buddhas were expounding were heard as if directly transmitted. Also visible were the bhikṣus, bhikṣuṇīs, upāsakas, and upāsikās who had cultivated the path through meditation and ethical practice and had thereby attained the Way.³⁸

Furthermore, the Bodhisattva-Mahāsattvas were seen practicing the Bodhisattva path through various causes and conditions, through various frames of understanding and belief, and through various appearances and manifestations adapted to their respective capacities.³⁹

Also seen were Buddhas entering parinirvāṇa (final transcendence)—a sight indicating the impermanent and conditional nature of even the Buddha's manifest form in the world.⁴⁰ Also seen, after those Buddhas' parinirvāṇa, were stūpas of the seven precious materials being erected and dedicated to preserve their sacred relics (śarīra).⁴¹

---

Maitreya's Inquiry

At that time, the Bodhisattva Maitreya⁴² had this thought: "Now the World-Honored One has manifested this extraordinary spiritual transformation and display of supernatural power. For what cause and condition has this auspicious sign appeared? The Buddha, the World-Honored One, has now entered into samādhi—this inconceivable manifestation of rare phenomena heretofore unprecedented. To whom should I pose my question? Who possesses the capacity to answer such a profound matter?"⁴³

Then he harbored this further thought: "This Mañjuśrī, the prince of the Dharma King, has previously drawn near and made offerings to immeasurable Buddhas of the past through countless eons. Surely he must have witnessed these rare signs before. I shall now inquire of him."⁴⁴

---

The Assembly's Collective Doubt

At that time, the bhikṣus, bhikṣuṇīs, upāsakas, upāsikās, and all the devas, nāgas, and other spirits all harbored this thought: "This extraordinary Buddha-light and display of spiritual power—of whom should we now inquire? To whom shall we address our questions?"⁴⁵

---

Maitreya Addresses Mañjuśrī

At that time, the Bodhisattva Maitreya, wishing to resolve his own doubt and observing the minds of the fourfold assembly—the bhikṣus, bhikṣuṇīs, upāsakas, upāsikās, and all the devas, nāgas, and spirits of the assembly—addressed Mañjuśrī directly, saying:

"For what cause and condition has this auspicious spiritual sign appeared? For what reason does the Buddha emit this great light, illuminating the eighteen thousand lands to the east, whereby all the magnificent adornments of those Buddha-lands are completely visible to us?"

---

Thereupon, the Bodhisattva Maitreya, wishing to restate this meaning in verse form, spoke the following inquiry:

### Mañjuśrī's Response: The Teaching of Skillful Means
[This section continues with Mañjuśrī's lengthy explanation, which forms the substantial core of Chapter 1. Due to length, the full verse and extended prose explanation follows here:]

Then the Bodhisattva Mañjuśrī addressed Maitreya and all the great Bodhisattvas and virtuous men assembled: "Based on what I understand and contemplate, the World-Honored One is about to expound the great Dharma. He will rain down the great Dharma rain, sound the great Dharma trumpet, and beat the great Dharma drum, in order to expound the great significance of the Dharma."⁴⁶

"O virtuous men, in ages past, spanning countless immeasurable eons prior to the present, there existed a Buddha named the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps (Dipamkara Buddha), one worthy of offerings, possessing perfect knowledge, perfect conduct, well-gone, knower of the world, supreme guide, trainer of men, teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One.⁴⁷ He expounded the correct Dharma—a teaching that was good at the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end, whose meaning was profound and far-reaching, whose language was skillfully composed, pure and simple without admixture, adorned with complete and perfect conduct befitting a Brahmin sage.⁴⁸

"To those seeking the status of Śrāvaka (disciple), he taught the Four Noble Truths,⁴⁹ enabling them to transcend birth, old age, sickness, and death, and ultimately attaining the perfect peace of nirvāṇa.⁵⁰ To those seeking the status of Pratyekabuddha (solitary awakener), he taught the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination.⁵¹ To the Bodhisattvas, he taught the Six Perfections (pāramitās),⁵² enabling them to attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi and perfect enlightenment, becoming endowed with all-knowing wisdom."⁵³

"Now, in succession to this Buddha, there appeared another Buddha, also named the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps. In fact, in this manner, there appeared a succession of twenty thousand Buddhas, all bearing the same name and title, all belonging to the same lineage. O Maitreya, you should know that the first Buddha and the last Buddha were all of the same name and title, called the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps, and all possessed the ten epithets.⁵⁴ The teachings they expounded were good at the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end."⁵⁵

"The last of these Buddhas of Burning Lamps, before he had renounced the household life and attained Buddhahood, had eight sons as a prince. Their names were: the Prince with Intention, the Prince of Good Intention, the Prince of Boundless Intention, the Prince of Jeweled Intention, the Prince of Increasing Intention, the Prince of Intention without Doubt, the Prince of Intention Directed Forward, and the Prince of Dharma Intention.⁵⁶

"O virtuous men, in ages past, spanning countless immeasurable eons prior to the present, there existed a Buddha named the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps (Dipamkara Buddha), one worthy of offerings, possessing perfect knowledge, perfect conduct, well-gone, knower of the world, supreme guide, trainer of men, teacher of gods and humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One.⁴⁷ He expounded the correct Dharma—a teaching that was good at the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end, whose meaning was profound and far-reaching, whose language was skillfully composed, pure and simple without admixture, adorned with complete and perfect conduct befitting a Brahmin sage.⁴⁸
"To those seeking the status of Śrāvaka (disciple), he taught the Four Noble Truths,⁴⁹ enabling them to transcend birth, old age, sickness, and death, and ultimately attaining the perfect peace of nirvāṇa.⁵⁰ To those seeking the status of Pratyekabuddha (solitary awakener), he taught the Twelve Links of Dependent Origination.⁵¹ To the Bodhisattvas, he taught the Six Perfections (pāramitās),⁵² enabling them to attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi and perfect enlightenment, becoming endowed with all-knowing wisdom."⁵³
"Now, in succession to this Buddha, there appeared another Buddha, also named the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps. In fact, in this manner, there appeared a succession of twenty thousand Buddhas, all bearing the same name and title, all belonging to the same lineage. O Maitreya, you should know that the first Buddha and the last Buddha were all of the same name and title, called the Tathāgata of Burning Lamps, and all possessed the ten epithets.⁵⁴ The teachings they expounded were good at the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end."⁵⁵
"The last of these Buddhas of Burning Lamps, before he had renounced the household life and attained Buddhahood, had eight sons as a prince. Their names were: the Prince with Intention, the Prince of Good Intention, the Prince of Boundless Intention, the Prince of Jeweled Intention, the Prince of Increasing Intention, the Prince of Intention without Doubt, the Prince of Intention Directed Forward, and the Prince of Dharma Intention.⁵⁶

2.title: Chapter 2: Skillful Means
2.prose_html:
The Buddha's Opening Teaching on Buddha-Wisdom

At that time, the World-Honored One, having emerged from meditation with composed serenity, addressed Śāriputra:¹

"The wisdom of the Buddhas, the Tathāgatas, is infinitely profound and immeasurable. The gateway to this wisdom is difficult to comprehend and difficult to enter—beyond the capacity of all Śrāvakas (disciples) and Pratyekabuddhas (solitary awakeners) to understand. Why is this?

"The Buddhas have approached and made offerings to hundreds of thousands of billions of Tathāgatas beyond number. They have completely practiced the infinite dharmic pathways of all the Buddhas. With courageous diligence, their renown has spread universally. They have accomplished teachings utterly unprecedented and extraordinary.²

"Their teachings, adapted to circumstances and conditions, are of meaning (arthas) most difficult to comprehend. Śāriputra, since my own attainment of Buddhahood, I have employed innumerable causes and conditions, boundless parables and illustrations, and infinite skilful means (upayā) to guide and transform all beings, enabling them to transcend all forms of attachment and clinging.³ Why is this?

"The Tathāgata has completely perfected the transcendent wisdom and vision of skilful means (upaya-jñāna-darsana). Śāriputra, the Tathāgata's wisdom and vision is boundless and vast, profound and far-reaching, infinite and unobstructed. His supernatural powers, fearlessness, meditative concentrations, liberations, and samadhis extend into the infinite and reach to the limit. The Tathāgata has accomplished teachings utterly unprecedented.

"Śāriputra, the Tathāgata is able to make distinctions among the various dharmas and to discourse skillfully upon them, employing words gentle and soft that bring joy to the hearts of all beings.⁴ Śāriputra, in essential summary, the Tathāgata has accomplished infinite, boundless, unprecedented teachings."⁵

---

The Buddha's Cessation: The Limits of Teaching

Then the Buddha said: "Cease, Śāriputra. There is no need to speak further. Why? The supremely rare and extraordinary teaching that the Buddha has accomplished—the dharma most difficult to understand—can only be fully penetrated and exhausted by the Buddha together with other Buddhas. I refer to the realm of reality in which:⁶

"The various dharmas possess such-like characteristics, such-like natures, such-like bodies, such-like powers, such-like activities, such-like causes, such-like conditions, such-like effects, such-like retributions, and such-like their beginning and end, their ultimate equivalence."⁷

---

bonds, > And to attain nirvāṇa. > > By the Buddha's skilful means-power, > I have shown the three-vehicle teaching, > And because sentient beings cling everywhere, > I guide them to liberation.
### The Assembly's Confusion

At that time, there were in the great assembly twelve hundred Śrāvakas who had exhausted all outflows and were Arhats, including Ājñātakauṇḍinya and others, as well as those among the bhikṣus and bhikṣuṇīs, male and female lay disciples who had generated the aspiration toward Śrāvaka and Pratyekabuddha vehicles. All of them harbored this thought:

"Why does the World-Honored One so earnestly praise skilful means (upaya) and speak in this manner? He says that the dharma obtained by the Buddha is profoundly difficult to comprehend, that what he speaks is of meaning difficult to discern, that it exceeds the capacity of all Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas to attain.
"The Buddha has spoken of one meaning of liberation,⁸ which we too have obtained, enabling us to reach nirvāṇa. Yet now we do not understand toward what end this teaching aims."⁹
### Śāriputra's Inquiry
At that time, Śāriputra, recognizing the perplexity in the hearts of the fourfold assembly and being himself uncertain, addressed the Buddha:

"World-Honored One, for what cause and condition do you so earnestly praise the supreme skilful means of all the Buddhas—that dharma most profoundly subtle and difficult to comprehend? Since ancient times, I have never heard from the Buddha such teaching as this. Now the fourfold assembly harbors doubt about this matter. I beseech you, World-Honored One, to elucidate this matter! Why do you so earnestly praise the dharma so profoundly subtle and difficult to comprehend?"¹⁰

3.title: Chapter 3: Parables
3.prose_html:
Śāriputra's Joy and Understanding

At that time, Śāriputra, overflowing with joy and delight, immediately rose from his seat, pressed his palms together in salutation, gazed upon the Buddha's face with reverent attention, and addressed the Buddha:

"Now, having heard this dharma-sound from the World-Honored One, my heart overflows with joy and I have experienced what has never been experienced before. Why is this?

"In ancient times, when I heard from the Buddha such a teaching as this, I saw that the various Bodhisattvas received prophecies of Buddhahood, yet I and my companions were not included in these events. I deeply sorrowed within myself, feeling that I had lost the infinite wisdom of the Tathāgata.¹

"World-Honored One, I have often dwelt alone in mountain forests and beneath trees, whether sitting or walking, constantly entertaining this thought: 'We have all entered into the dharma-nature equally—why then does the Tathāgata appear to guide us through the small vehicle?' This fault lies with us, not with the World-Honored One. Why is this?

"Had we expected the teaching of that which would enable us to achieve anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, we would surely have been liberated through the great vehicle. However, we did not understand the skilful means of adaptive teaching according to circumstances. Upon first hearing the Buddha's teaching, we encountered it and immediately generated faith, contemplated it, and claimed realization.

"World-Honored One, since ancient times I have continuously and throughout day and night reproached myself. Yet now, having heard from the Buddha teachings never before heard, unprecedented dharmas, I have severed all doubt and regret. My body and mind are at peace, my heart is utterly tranquil. Today I truly understand that I am a Buddha-child, born from the Buddha's mouth, born from the dharma, and possessed of the Buddha-dharma inheritance."²

---
verses: ### Śāriputra's Verse of Joy
Then Śāriputra, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke in verse:

> Having heard this dharma-sound, > I have obtained what was never before experienced, > My heart overflows with great joy, > And all my nets of doubt have been severed. > > In the past, receiving the Buddha's teaching, > I did not lose the great vehicle, > The Buddha's sound is supremely rare, > Able to remove all sentient beings' afflictions. > > I have already exhausted all outflows, > And this hearing has removed my distress. > I dwelt in valleys > Or beneath forest trees, > > Whether sitting or walking in meditation, > I constantly contemplated this matter, > Grieving deeply and reproaching myself: > How could I deceive myself? > > We too are Buddha-children, > Having entered into the unconditioned dharma together, > Yet I have been unable in the future, > To expound the supreme path. > > The thirty-two marks of gold, > The ten powers and all liberations, > Shared within one dharma, > Yet I did not obtain this. > > The eighty wonderful characteristics, > The eighteen dharmas unique to Buddhas, > And such meritorious qualities as these, > I have altogether lost. > > During my solitary practice, walking, > I saw the Buddha in the great assembly, > His renown filling the ten directions, > Bringing immeasurable benefit to all beings. > > I contemplated how I had lost this benefit, > And knew that I had deceived myself. > Constantly throughout day and night, > I contemplated this matter, > > Wishing to question the World-Honored One, > Whether I had lost or not lost this, > I constantly saw the World-Honored One, > Praising the various Bodhisattvas. > > Because of this, throughout day and night, > I deliberated upon this matter. > Now, hearing the Buddha's voice, > Teaching the dharma according to circumstances, > > The unconditioned, inconceivable dharma, > That brings all beings to enlightenment. > I was originally attached to perverted views, > A teacher to all the Brahmin ascetics. > > The World-Honored One knew my mind, > And uprooted my perverted views by teaching nirvāṇa. > I have completely eliminated perverted views, > And realized the dharma of emptiness. > > At that time, my mind believed, > That I had attained extinction. > Yet now I have suddenly awakened, > That this is not true extinction. > > When I obtain Buddhahood, > Possessing the thirty-two marks, > The devas, humans, yakshas, > And dragon-beings showing reverence, > > Only then can it be truly said, > That extinction has been completed without remainder. > The Buddha, in the great assembly, > Has taught that I shall become a Buddha. > > Having heard such dharma-sound, > All my doubt and regret have been severed. > When I first heard what the Buddha taught, > My heart harbored great astonishment and doubt, > > "Could this be the work of Māra, > Creating a false Buddha, disturbing my mind?" > The Buddha, through various causes and conditions, > Parables and skillfully chosen words, spoke, > > And my heart became calm as the ocean, > My nets of doubt were severed upon hearing. > The Buddha spoke of past world-ages, > Countless Buddhas who had passed away, > > Who dwell within skilful means, > And all taught this very dharma. > The Buddhas of the present and future, > Are boundless in number, > > And also through skilful means, > Expound this dharma likewise. > Just as the World-Honored One of today, > From birth and renunciation of family life, > > Attained the path and turned the dharma-wheel, > Also teaching through skilful means. > The World-Honored One speaks the true path— > Māra has no such accomplishment. > > Therefore, I know with certainty, > That this is not the work of Māra. > I had fallen into nets of doubt, > Thinking it was Māra's doing. > > Upon hearing the Buddha's gentle and soft voice, > Profoundly mysterious and supremely subtle, > Expounding the pure dharma, > My heart was filled with great joy. > > Doubt and regret have forever been severed, > And I dwell firmly in true wisdom. > I shall certainly become a Buddha, > Honored by devas and humans, > > Turn the supreme dharma-wheel, > And teach the various Bodhisattvas.
### The Buddha's Prophecy for Śāriputra

Then the Buddha addressed Śāriputra: "Now I speak before the assembly of devas, humans, monks, and Brahmins: I previously, for immeasurable billions of eons, in the presence of twenty billion Buddhas, for the sake of achieving the supreme path, continually taught and transformed you. You also, for countless nights, followed me and received my teaching.

"Because I guided you through skilful means, you were born within my teaching. Śāriputra, in the past I taught you to aspire to the Buddha path. You have now forgotten this, and thus you presume you have already attained extinction. Now I wish to cause you to recollect your original vow and the path you cultivated. For this reason, for all the Śrāvakas I teach this great-vehicle sutra, called the Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma Lotus Flower, the teaching for Bodhisattvas, protected and remembered by all the Buddhas."³
### Śāriputra's Future Buddhahood

"Śāriputra, in the future world, after passing through immeasurable, boundless, inconceivable eons, having made offerings to countless billions of Buddhas, upheld the correct dharma, perfected the bodhisattva path, you shall become a Buddha with the title Tathāgata of Radiant Flower, Worthy of Offerings, Possessor of Perfect Knowledge, Possessor of Perfect Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the World, Unsurpassed Guide, Trainer of Beings, Teacher of Devas and Humans, Buddha, World-Honored One.

"The land will be named Pure Radiance, its earth level and even, supremely pure and beautifully adorned, secure and prosperous, with abundance of devas and humans. Its ground shall be made of lapis lazuli, with eight crossways adorned with golden boundaries. Throughout the realm shall grow seven-jeweled trees, eternally bearing flowers and fruit. The Tathāgata of Radiant Flower shall also teach the three vehicles to sentient beings."⁴
### The Golden Age of Radiant Flower Buddha

mysterious and supremely subtle, > Expounding the pure dharma, > My heart was filled with great joy. > > Doubt and regret have forever been severed, > And I dwell firmly in true wisdom. > I shall certainly become a Buddha, > Honored by devas and humans, > > Turn the supreme dharma-wheel, > And teach the various Bodhisattvas.
### The Buddha's Prophecy for Śāriputra
Then the Buddha addressed Śāriputra: "Now I speak before the assembly of devas, humans, monks, and Brahmins: I previously, for immeasurable billions of eons, in the presence of twenty billion Buddhas, for the sake of achieving the supreme path, continually taught and transformed you. You also, for countless nights, followed me and received my teaching.
"Because I guided you through skilful means, you were born within my teaching. Śāriputra, in the past I taught you to aspire to the Buddha path. You have now forgotten this, and thus you presume you have already attained extinction. Now I wish to cause you to recollect your original vow and the path you cultivated. For this reason, for all the Śrāvakas I teach this great-vehicle sutra, called the Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma Lotus Flower, the teaching for Bodhisattvas, protected and remembered by all the Buddhas."³
### Śāriputra's Future Buddhahood
"Śāriputra, in the future world, after passing through immeasurable, boundless, inconceivable eons, having made offerings to countless billions of Buddhas, upheld the correct dharma, perfected the bodhisattva path, you shall become a Buddha with the title Tathāgata of Radiant Flower, Worthy of Offerings, Possessor of Perfect Knowledge, Possessor of Perfect Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the World, Unsurpassed Guide, Trainer of Beings, Teacher of Devas and Humans, Buddha, World-Honored One.
"The land will be named Pure Radiance, its earth level and even, supremely pure and beautifully adorned, secure and prosperous, with abundance of devas and humans. Its ground shall be made of lapis lazuli, with eight crossways adorned with golden boundaries. Throughout the realm shall grow seven-jeweled trees, eternally bearing flowers and fruit. The Tathāgata of Radiant Flower shall also teach the three vehicles to sentient beings."⁴
### The Golden Age of Radiant Flower Buddha

4.title: Chapter 4: Faith and Understanding
4.prose_html:
The Four Great Disciples' Joy and Recognition

At that time, the wise Subhūti, Mahākātyāyana, Mahākāśyapa, and Mahāmaudgalyāyana, having heard from the Buddha this unprecedented teaching, with the World-Honored One granting prophecy of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi to Śāriputra, their hearts were moved with wonder and delight. They immediately rose from their seats, straightened their robes, uncovered their right shoulders in respectful posture, knelt upon their right knees, unified their minds by placing their palms together in reverent salutation, bowed deeply in respect, gazed upon the Buddha's countenance with undivided attention, and addressed the Buddha:

"World-Honored One, we are elders among the assembled monks, advanced in age, and we have long believed that we had already attained nirvāṇa and had no further capacity for spiritual attainment. We harbored no aspiration to advance toward anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi.

"World-Honored One, in ages past when you taught the dharma at length, we sat in the assembly, but our bodies were weary and lethargic. We contemplated only emptiness, signlessness, and non-activity. Regarding the Bodhisattva dharma—the display of supernatural powers, the purification of Buddha-lands, and the perfection of sentient beings—our hearts did not delight in these teachings. Why was this?

"The World-Honored One caused us to escape from the three worlds and attain the realization of nirvāṇa. Moreover, at this time we are advanced in age. Toward the Buddha's teaching and transformation of Bodhisattvas aspiring to anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, we have not generated even a single thought of joy.

"Yet now, before the Buddha, we have heard the prophecy that we too shall attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi as Śrāvakas (voice-hearers). Our hearts are extremely joyful—we have experienced what we had never experienced before. We did not anticipate that at this time we would suddenly hear such a rare teaching. We deeply rejoice and feel that we have obtained great benefit, acquiring precious treasures without having sought them."¹

---

The Parable of the Prodigal Son: Introduction

"World-Honored One, we now wish to speak in parable to clarify this meaning:

"There was a man who, in his youth, ignorant and without understanding, abandoned his father and fled, dwelling in another land for a long time—ten, twenty, or even fifty years.² In his advancing age, he became impoverished and, wandering in all directions seeking clothing and food, gradually traveled and eventually arrived near his native land.

"His father, having long sought to find his son without success, had settled in a certain city. His household was immensely wealthy, with treasures beyond measure—gold, silver, lapis lazuli, coral, amber, crystal, pearls—all his storehouses completely filled and overflowing. He had numerous servants, officials, retainers, and common people. He possessed countless elephants, horses, chariots, ox-carts, and sheep. His wealth was engaged in business, spreading throughout other lands, and there were many merchants and traders. His father's thoughts constantly turned to his lost son.

"At that time, the impoverished son, seeking employment and wandering through villages and traveling through districts, eventually arrived at the city where his father had settled. His father had long mourned his son, and he and his son had been separated for more than fifty years. Yet the father never spoke of this matter to others. He merely thought within himself, harboring regret in his heart. He contemplated: 'I am old and approaching the end of life. I possess abundant wealth and treasures—gold, silver, precious jewels—my storehouses are completely full. But I have no son to whom I can entrust these riches. One day I shall die, and my wealth shall scatter and be lost with nothing to which it can be consigned. This is why I am constantly concerned and every moment remember my son.'

"Furthermore, he formed this thought: 'If I could only obtain my son and entrust him with my wealth, I would be at ease and happiness, without further worries.'"³

---

The Encounter: The Son Becomes Afraid

"World-Honored One, at that time the impoverished son, having hired himself to various employers, eventually arrived at his father's dwelling. He stood beside the gate. From a distance, he saw his father, seated upon a magnificent throne, his feet resting upon a precious footrest. Brahmins, nobles, and merchants all paid him respectful reverence. His body was adorned with pearls and precious ornaments worth thousands of millions of coins. Officials, servants, and retainers held white fly-whisks, standing to his left and right. A jeweled canopy was suspended above him, with precious flower banners hanging down. Fragrant water had been sprinkled on the ground, and precious flowers were scattered about. Precious objects were arrayed in display, brought in and taken out for distribution. Such was the variety of his magnificent adornment, and his authority and dignity were specially exalted.

"The impoverished son, seeing his father possessed of such great power and majesty, immediately became filled with fear and regret for having come to this place. He secretly formed this thought:

"'This man may be a king or the equal of a king. He is certainly not a place where I can earn a livelihood through manual labor. It would be better for me to go to a poor village where I might have a place to exert my strength, where food and clothing can be easily obtained. If I remain here for a long time, I might be constrained and forced to labor.'

"Forming this thought, he hastily fled."⁴

---

The Father's Recognition and Gentle Retrieval

"At that time the wealthy householder, seated upon his throne, recognized his son immediately and his heart was filled with great joy. He formed this thought:

"'Now I have someone to whom I can entrust my wealth and treasures. I have constantly thought of this son, yet had no means to see him. Unexpectedly, he has come—this accords perfectly with my wish. Although I am advanced in age, my desires remain strong.'

"He immediately sent attendants to pursue and bring back his son. At that moment, the messenger hastily ran after the poor son to capture him. The poor son, startled and alarmed, cried out in protest:

"'I have committed no offense against you—why do you seize me?'

"The messenger held him even more tightly and forcibly dragged him back. At that time, the poor son, thinking that he had committed no transgression yet was being imprisoned and seized, believed his death was certain, and his terror increased. He became unconscious and collapsed to the ground.

"The father, observing this from a distance, instructed the messenger:

"'Release this person! Do not forcibly bring him. Sprinkle cold water on his face to revive him, and do not speak to him further.'

"Why was this? The father understood that his son, possessed of inferior spiritual capacity, was intimidated by the father's power and wealth, which the son found difficult to comprehend. Although the father clearly knew this was indeed his son, he employed skilful means, not telling other people that this was his son.

"The messenger told the son:

"'I now release you. Go wherever you wish.'

"The poor son was delighted to obtain what he had not expected. He rose from the ground and went to a poor village, seeking employment and food."⁵

---

The Father's Strategy: Gradual Approach

"At that time, the householder, desiring to entice and guide his son through the employment of skilful means, secretly sent two people of humble appearance, without power or prestige:

"'You may go to that place and gradually speak to the poor son, saying: "This place has work available. We shall pay you double wages. If the poor son accepts, bring him here and have him work. If he asks what kind of work it is, tell him: 'We shall hire you to clean excrement. We two shall also work with you.'"'

"The two messengers immediately sought out the poor son, and having found him, explained everything in detail. At that time, the poor son, first receiving payment, immediately began cleaning excrement with them.

"His father, observing his son, felt compassion and was amazed. On another day, peering through a window, the father saw his son—thin and gaunt, his appearance withered and shrunk, his body covered with filth and dust, unclean. Immediately the father removed his ornaments, fine clothing, and adornments, and instead put on coarse, worn, dirty garments, his body covered with dust. Holding a dung-removal implement in his right hand, with an expression showing reverence, he instructed the workers:

"'You all must work diligently without laziness!'

"By employing skilful means in this way, he was able to draw near his son. Later, he spoke to the son:

"'Listen, young man! You should continue this work here. Do not leave to seek other employment. I shall increase your wages. Whatever you need—bowls, rice, noodles, salt, vinegar, and such things—do not hesitate to ask. We have old, worn servants who can provide whatever you need. Make yourself comfortable. I am to you as a father. Do not worry further. Why is this? I am old and advanced in years, while you are young and vigorous. When you work, you show neither deception nor laziness, neither anger nor complaint. I see no such faults in you as I see in other workers. From this time forward, I shall regard you as a son.'

"At that moment, the householder gave him a new name, calling him 'child.' At that time, the poor son, although delighted by this favorable treatment, still regarded himself as a hired servant. Because of this, for twenty years, he continued to clean excrement. After this period had passed, his mind gradually grew familiar and trusting. He came and went without hindrance, yet he still remained in his former dwelling place."⁶

---

The Father's Deathbed Revelation

"World-Honored One, at that time the householder became ill, and knowing that death was approaching, he spoke to his son:

"'I now possess abundant gold, silver, and precious treasures, and my storehouses are completely filled. I know precisely how much is there and what should be given and taken. You should understand all of this. My heart is thus. You should comprehend this intention. Why? Now I and you are not different—you should apply your heart fully so that nothing is lost.'

"At that time the poor son, having received the instruction, took charge of all the treasures, gold, silver, precious jewels, and storehouses, yet harbored no hope of taking even a single meal's worth. Yet his dwelling place still remained his former location, and he had not yet abandoned his sense of inferiority. After another brief period, the father understood his son's mind was gradually becoming broader and more expansive, and he had achieved a noble aspiration, scorning his former inferior thoughts.

"At the time approaching the father's death, he summoned his son together with his relatives, the king, great ministers, nobles, and wealthy merchants—all having assembled—and he himself made this declaration:

"'All you gentlemen should know: This is my son, whom I fathered. In a certain city, he abandoned me and fled. For more than fifty years, impoverished and suffering hardship, he has been lost. His original name is [such and such], and my name is [such and such]. Long ago in my native city, filled with concern, I sought for him, but suddenly, unexpectedly, I encountered and found him in this place. This is truly my son, and I am truly his father. All my wealth and possessions are now his. All that I previously gave out and took in, he now knows.'

"World-Honored One, at that time the poor son, hearing these words of his father, was suddenly overwhelmed with great joy and experienced what he had never experienced before. He formed this thought:

"'I never harbored any thought of seeking or hoping for anything, yet now this treasury of precious wealth has naturally come to me.'"⁷

---

The Interpretation: The Buddha's Application

"World-Honored One, the wealthy householder is the Tathāgata. We all, in like manner, are Buddha-children. The Tathāgata constantly speaks of us as his children.

"World-Honored One, we have undergone the three sufferings within birth and death, experiencing various afflictions, confusion, and ignorance, delighting in and clinging to the small dharma. Today the World-Honored One has caused us to contemplate and abandon the excrement of conceptual elaboration regarding all dharmas. We diligently cultivated within this, obtaining the single day's wage of nirvāṇa, and, having obtained this, our hearts were greatly joyful. We believed this was a great attainment and said to ourselves: 'Through diligent cultivation in the Buddha's dharma, what we have obtained is abundant.'

"However, the World-Honored One previously knew that our hearts were attached to inferior desires and delighted in the small dharma. He therefore allowed us to cease, without making distinctions, that you would all share in the treasury of the Tathāgata's wisdom and vision. The World-Honored One, through the power of skilful means, explained the Buddha-wisdom, and we, from the Buddha, obtained the single day's wage of nirvāṇa, regarding it as a great attainment. Toward this great vehicle, we have harbored no aspirational seeking.

"We likewise, because of the Tathāgata's wisdom, have disclosed and explained the Bodhisattva dharma to the various Bodhisattvas, yet we ourselves have harbored no aspiration. Why? Because the Buddha knew that our hearts delight in the small dharma, through the power of skilful means and following our capacities, the Buddha taught us. Yet we did not know that we were truly Buddha-children.

"Now we truly understand that the World-Honored One harbors no stinginess regarding the Buddha-wisdom. Why? We have truly been Buddha-children since ancient times, yet have only delighted in the small dharma. If we had harbored the heart of delight in the great, the Buddha would have taught us the great-vehicle dharma. In this sutra, only the One Vehicle is taught, whereas in the past, before the Bodhisattvas, we disparaged the voice-hearers who delight in the small dharma. Yet the Buddha truly employed the great vehicle to teach and transform us. Therefore, we say: We originally harbored no aspiration to seek anything. Now the precious dharma-king treasure has naturally come to us, and all that Buddha-children should obtain, we have already obtained."⁸

---

Chapter 4: Faith and Understanding

The Four Great Disciples' Joy and Recognition

At that time, the wise Subhūti, Mahākātyāyana, Mahākāśyapa, and Mahāmaudgalyāyana, having heard from the Buddha this unprecedented teaching, with the World-Honored One granting prophecy of anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi to Śāriputra, their hearts were moved with wonder and delight. They immediately rose from their seats, straightened their robes, uncovered their right shoulders in respectful posture, knelt upon their right knees, unified their minds by placing their palms together in reverent salutation, bowed deeply in respect, gazed upon the Buddha's countenance with undivided attention, and addressed the Buddha:

"World-Honored One, we are elders among the assembled monks, advanced in age, and we have long believed that we had already attained nirvāṇa and had no further capacity for spiritual attainment. We harbored no aspiration to advance toward anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi.

"World-Honored One, in ages past when you taught the dharma at length, we sat in the assembly, but our bodies were weary and lethargic. We contemplated only emptiness, signlessness, and non-activity. Regarding the Bodhisattva dharma—the display of supernatural powers, the purification of Buddha-lands, and the perfection of sentient beings—our hearts did not delight in these teachings. Why was this?

"The World-Honored One caused us to escape from the three worlds and attain the realization of nirvāṇa. Moreover, at this time we are advanced in age. Toward the Buddha's teaching and transformation of Bodhisattvas aspiring to anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi, we have not generated even a single thought of joy.

"Yet now, before the Buddha, we have heard the prophecy that we too shall attain anuttara-samyak-saṃbodhi as Śrāvakas (voice-hearers). Our hearts are extremely joyful—we have experienced what we had never experienced before. We did not anticipate that at this time we would suddenly hear such a rare teaching. We deeply rejoice and feel that we have obtained great benefit, acquiring precious treasures without having sought them."¹

---

The Parable of the Prodigal Son: Introduction

"World-Honored One, we now wish to speak in parable to clarify this meaning:

"There was a man who, in his youth, ignorant and without understanding, abandoned his father and fled, dwelling in another land for a long time—ten, twenty, or even fifty years.² In his advancing age, he became impoverished and, wandering in all directions seeking clothing and food, gradually traveled and eventually arrived near his native land.

"His father, having long sought to find his son without success, had settled in a certain city. His household was immensely wealthy, with treasures beyond measure—gold, silver, lapis lazuli, coral, amber, crystal, pearls—all his storehouses completely filled and overflowing. He had numerous servants, officials, retainers, and common people. He possessed countless elephants, horses, chariots, ox-carts, and sheep. His wealth was engaged in business, spreading throughout other lands, and there were many merchants and traders. His father's thoughts constantly turned to his lost son.

"At that time, the impoverished son, seeking employment and wandering through villages and traveling through districts, eventually arrived at the city where his father had settled. His father had long mourned his son, and he and his son had been separated for more than fifty years. Yet the father never spoke of this matter to others. He merely thought within himself, harboring regret in his heart. He contemplated: 'I am old and approaching the end of life. I possess abundant wealth and treasures—gold, silver, precious jewels—my storehouses are completely full. But I have no son to whom I can entrust these riches. One day I shall die, and my wealth shall scatter and be lost with nothing to which it can be consigned. This is why I am constantly concerned and every moment remember my son.'

"Furthermore, he formed this thought: 'If I could only obtain my son and entrust him with my wealth, I would be at ease and happiness, without further worries.'"³

---

The Encounter: The Son Becomes Afraid

"World-Honored One, at that time the impoverished son, having hired himself to various employers, eventually arrived at his father's dwelling. He stood beside the gate. From a distance, he saw his father, seated upon a magnificent throne, his feet resting upon a precious footrest. Brahmins, nobles, and merchants all paid him respectful reverence. His body was adorned with pearls and precious ornaments worth thousands of millions of coins. Officials, servants, and retainers held white fly-whisks, standing to his left and right. A jeweled canopy was suspended above him, with precious flower banners hanging down. Fragrant water had been sprinkled on the ground, and precious flowers were scattered about. Precious objects were arrayed in display, brought in and taken out for distribution. Such was the variety of his magnificent adornment, and his authority and dignity were specially exalted.

"The impoverished son, seeing his father possessed of such great power and majesty, immediately became filled with fear and regret for having come to this place. He secretly formed this thought:

"'This man may be a king or the equal of a king. He is certainly not a place where I can earn a livelihood through manual labor. It would be better for me to go to a poor village where I might have a place to exert my strength, where food and clothing can be easily obtained. If I remain here for a long time, I might be constrained and forced to labor.'

"Forming this thought, he hastily fled."⁴

---

The Father's Recognition and Gentle Retrieval

"At that time the wealthy householder, seated upon his throne, recognized his son immediately and his heart was filled with great joy. He formed this thought:

"'Now I have someone to whom I can entrust my wealth and treasures. I have constantly thought of this son, yet had no means to see him. Unexpectedly, he has come—this accords perfectly with my wish. Although I am advanced in age, my desires remain strong.'

"He immediately sent attendants to pursue and bring back his son. At that moment, the messenger hastily ran after the poor son to capture him. The poor son, startled and alarmed, cried out in protest:

"'I have committed no offense against you—why do you seize me?'

"The messenger held him even more tightly and forcibly dragged him back. At that time, the poor son, thinking that he had committed no transgression yet was being imprisoned and seized, believed his death was certain, and his terror increased. He became unconscious and collapsed to the ground.

"The father, observing this from a distance, instructed the messenger:

"'Release this person! Do not forcibly bring him. Sprinkle cold water on his face to revive him, and do not speak to him further.'

"Why was this? The father understood that his son, possessed of inferior spiritual capacity, was intimidated by the father's power and wealth, which the son found difficult to comprehend. Although the father clearly knew this was indeed his son, he employed skilful means, not telling other people that this was his son.

"The messenger told the son:

"'I now release you. Go wherever you wish.'

"The poor son was delighted to obtain what he had not expected. He rose from the ground and went to a poor village, seeking employment and food."⁵

---

The Father's Strategy: Gradual Approach

"At that time, the householder, desiring to entice and guide his son through the employment of skilful means, secretly sent two people of humble appearance, without power or prestige:

"'You may go to that place and gradually speak to the poor son, saying: "This place has work available. We shall pay you double wages. If the poor son accepts, bring him here and have him work. If he asks what kind of work it is, tell him: 'We shall hire you to clean excrement. We two shall also work with you.'"'

"The two messengers immediately sought out the poor son, and having found him, explained everything in detail. At that time, the poor son, first receiving payment, immediately began cleaning excrement with them.

"His father, observing his son, felt compassion and was amazed. On another day, peering through a window, the father saw his son—thin and gaunt, his appearance withered and shrunk, his body covered with filth and dust, unclean. Immediately the father removed his ornaments, fine clothing, and adornments, and instead put on coarse, worn, dirty garments, his body covered with dust. Holding a dung-removal implement in his right hand, with an expression showing reverence, he instructed the workers:

"'You all must work diligently without laziness!'

"By employing skilful means in this way, he was able to draw near his son. Later, he spoke to the son:

"'Listen, young man! You should continue this work here. Do not leave to seek other employment. I shall increase your wages. Whatever you need—bowls, rice, noodles, salt, vinegar, and such things—do not hesitate to ask. We have old, worn servants who can provide whatever you need. Make yourself comfortable. I am to you as a father. Do not worry further. Why is this? I am old and advanced in years, while you are young and vigorous. When you work, you show neither deception nor laziness, neither anger nor complaint. I see no such faults in you as I see in other workers. From this time forward, I shall regard you as a son.'

"At that moment, the householder gave him a new name, calling him 'child.' At that time, the poor son, although delighted by this favorable treatment, still regarded himself as a hired servant. Because of this, for twenty years, he continued to clean excrement. After this period had passed, his mind gradually grew familiar and trusting. He came and went without hindrance, yet he still remained in his former dwelling place."⁶

---

The Father's Deathbed Revelation

"World-Honored One, at that time the householder became ill, and knowing that death was approaching, he spoke to his son:

"'I now possess abundant gold, silver, and precious treasures, and my storehouses are completely filled. I know precisely how much is there and what should be given and taken. You should understand all of this. My heart is thus. You should comprehend this intention. Why? Now I and you are not different—you should apply your heart fully so that nothing is lost.'

"At that time the poor son, having received the instruction, took charge of all the treasures, gold, silver, precious jewels, and storehouses, yet harbored no hope of taking even a single meal's worth. Yet his dwelling place still remained his former location, and he had not yet abandoned his sense of inferiority. After another brief period, the father understood his son's mind was gradually becoming broader and more expansive, and he had achieved a noble aspiration, scorning his former inferior thoughts.

"At the time approaching the father's death, he summoned his son together with his relatives, the king, great ministers, nobles, and wealthy merchants—all having assembled—and he himself made this declaration:

"'All you gentlemen should know: This is my son, whom I fathered. In a certain city, he abandoned me and fled. For more than fifty years, impoverished and suffering hardship, he has been lost. His original name is [such and such], and my name is [such and such]. Long ago in my native city, filled with concern, I sought for him, but suddenly, unexpectedly, I encountered and found him in this place. This is truly my son, and I am truly his father. All my wealth and possessions are now his. All that I previously gave out and took in, he now knows.'

"World-Honored One, at that time the poor son, hearing these words of his father, was suddenly overwhelmed with great joy and experienced what he had never experienced before. He formed this thought:

"'I never harbored any thought of seeking or hoping for anything, yet now this treasury of precious wealth has naturally come to me.'"⁷

---

The Interpretation: The Buddha's Application

"World-Honored One, the wealthy householder is the Tathāgata. We all, in like manner, are Buddha-children. The Tathāgata constantly speaks of us as his children.

"World-Honored One, we have undergone the three sufferings within birth and death, experiencing various afflictions, confusion, and ignorance, delighting in and clinging to the small dharma. Today the World-Honored One has caused us to contemplate and abandon the excrement of conceptual elaboration regarding all dharmas. We diligently cultivated within this, obtaining the single day's wage of nirvāṇa, and, having obtained this, our hearts were greatly joyful. We believed this was a great attainment and said to ourselves: 'Through diligent cultivation in the Buddha's dharma, what we have obtained is abundant.'

"However, the World-Honored One previously knew that our hearts were attached to inferior desires and delighted in the small dharma. He therefore allowed us to cease, without making distinctions, that you would all share in the treasury of the Tathāgata's wisdom and vision. The World-Honored One, through the power of skilful means, explained the Buddha-wisdom, and we, from the Buddha, obtained the single day's wage of nirvāṇa, regarding it as a great attainment. Toward this great vehicle, we have harbored no aspirational seeking.

"We likewise, because of the Tathāgata's wisdom, have disclosed and explained the Bodhisattva dharma to the various Bodhisattvas, yet we ourselves have harbored no aspiration. Why? Because the Buddha knew that our hearts delight in the small dharma, through the power of skilful means and following our capacities, the Buddha taught us. Yet we did not know that we were truly Buddha-children.

"Now we truly understand that the World-Honored One harbors no stinginess regarding the Buddha-wisdom. Why? We have truly been Buddha-children since ancient times, yet have only delighted in the small dharma. If we had harbored the heart of delight in the great, the Buddha would have taught us the great-vehicle dharma. In this sutra, only the One Vehicle is taught, whereas in the past, before the Bodhisattvas, we disparaged the voice-hearers who delight in the small dharma. Yet the Buddha truly employed the great vehicle to teach and transform us. Therefore, we say: We originally harbored no aspiration to seek anything. Now the precious dharma-king treasure has naturally come to us, and all that Buddha-children should obtain, we have already obtained."⁸

5.title: Chapter 5: Medicinal Herbs
5.prose_html:
The Medicinal Herbs parable completes the foundational teaching arc initiated in Chapters 2-4. Where Chapter 2 established the One Buddha Vehicle as the ultimate reality underlying apparent multiplicity, Chapter 3 showed how the Buddha employs skillful means to guide beings to safety, and Chapter 4 demonstrated how beings gradually recognize their inherent Buddha-nature, Chapter 5 now reveals the principle governing this process: the Buddha's single teaching is like a universal rain that nourishes all beings according to their nature and capacity.

This chapter addresses a crucial question implicit in the previous teachings: If the dharma is truly one, and all beings possess Buddha-nature, how do we account for the evident differences in beings' spiritual attainment and the varying paths they follow? The answer lies not in the dharma itself, but in the differential capacity of recipients—a principle with profound implications for understanding both Buddhist metaphysics and contemporary systems theory.

---

## The Buddha's Address to Mahākāśyapa

At this point in the assembly, the Buddha turns directly to Mahākāśyapa, one of the great disciples, and affirms what has been taught:

"Excellent! Excellent, Mahākāśyapa. You have spoken well of the Tathāgata's true virtues. Indeed, the Tathāgata possesses measureless, inconceivable merits that could not be exhausted even if explained throughout countless kalpas. Mahākāśyapa, understand this: the Tathāgata is the sovereign of all dharmas. Whatever the Tathāgata proclaims is never false. Through wisdom and skillful means, the Tathāgata expounds all dharmas, and every dharma taught reaches the domain of all-knowing wisdom."¹

This affirmation accomplishes several things simultaneously. First, it establishes the Buddha's omniscience—not as magical knowledge, but as complete understanding of the nature of reality and the conditions for liberation. Second, it emphasizes that this understanding is expressed through wisdom and skillful means—the pedagogical method that adapts eternal truth to particular circumstances.² Third, it asserts that all teachings lead to the same destination: "all-knowing wisdom" (一切智地), the recognition of the interconnected nature of reality itself.

¹ Textual Note [T.9.262, p.11-12]: The phrase "all-knowing wisdom" (一切智地) uses 地 (ground/domain), suggesting wisdom as the foundational reality underlying all phenomena, not merely intellectual achievement.

² Philosophical Note: This parallels Heidegger's distinction between ontic knowledge (particular facts) and ontological understanding (the structure of Being itself). The Buddha's skillful means operate at the ontological level.

## The Medicinal Herbs Parable: The Central Metaphor

The Buddha then presents the parable:

"Mahākāśyapa, consider this: In the entire threefold thousand-fold great thousand-world system, with all its mountains, valleys, and streams, there grow medicinal herbs, forests, and shrubs of countless kinds—each with its own form, name, and character. Then a great cloud arises, dense and voluminous, spreading and enveloping the entire threefold thousand-fold great thousand-world system. At a single moment, rain pours down equally, and its waters saturate everywhere."³

This opening establishes the scale and universality of what follows. The "threefold thousand-fold great thousand-world system" (三千大千世界) is not merely geographic; it represents the entire cosmos of sentient experience, encompassing all realms of existence from hell-beings to celestial realms.⁴ The dense cloud is not localized—it covers everything indiscriminately. The rain is singular in origin, yet its effects are manifold.

³ Scientific Parallel: The metaphor of a single rain nourishing diverse organisms according to their nature anticipates modern systems theory's insight that the same physical principle (e.g., water, energy, information) produces differentiated effects when interfacing with systems of different complexity and structure. Compare to how a single photon of light, when received by different organisms (bacteria, plants, eyes), produces entirely different adaptive responses based on each system's receptive capacities.

⁴ Cosmological Note [Ch.1, Cosmic Assembly]: See Chapter 1's description of the cosmic assembly, which establishes the existence of multiple realms as literal dimensions of reality—not metaphorical. The Medicinal Herbs teaching applies across all these realms.

The parable then develops the crucial distinction:

"Now, in that region grow medicinal herbs—small roots, small stems, small branches, small leaves; medium roots, medium stems, medium branches, medium leaves; large roots, large stems, large branches, large leaves. Trees of various sizes stand similarly ranked by upper, middle, and lower grades. Each receives precisely according to its species-nature. Although all are nourished by a single rain, each grass and tree develops distinctly according to its own kind."⁵

This passage is deceptively simple. The repetition of "small, medium, large" establishes a complete spectrum of recipients. Yet the critical point is this: The difference in growth is not due to difference in the rain, but to difference in the receptive capacity of the plants themselves. The rain is absolutely undifferentiated; the differentiation occurs in the interface between the rain and the plants receiving it.⁶

This principle has profound philosophical implications. It suggests that apparent inequality in spiritual achievement does not reflect inequality in the teaching or in beings' fundamental nature, but rather in their capacity to receive and embody the teaching. This is consistent with the Buddha-nature teaching (Chapter 4) while simultaneously explaining diversity.

⁵ Philosophical Connection [Compare to Chapter 4 - Prodigal Son]: Whereas the Prodigal Son parable emphasized the prodigal son's psychological journey from alienation to recognition, the Medicinal Herbs parable emphasizes the ontological principle governing all such journeys. Every journey of realization follows the same pattern because all beings interface with the same dharma through their particular nature.

⁶ Systems Theory Parallel: This exemplifies the principle of differentiated response to uniform input, central to contemporary complexity theory. A single signal (the rain) produces entirely different outputs depending on the structure and state of the receiving system. Similar dynamics appear in neural networks (same firing rule produces different computations based on weights), ecological systems (same nutrient availability supports different species), and information processing (same signal interpreted differently by different receivers).

## Application: The Buddha as the Great Cloud

The Buddha now applies this metaphor directly:

"Mahākāśyapa, the Tathāgata appears in the world precisely as this great cloud appears. Like that great cloud spreading over the threefold thousand-fold great thousand-world system, the Tathāgata speaks with a great voice, proclaiming to all gods, humans, and asuras:
'I am the Tathāgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One Possessed of Luminous Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer of Beings, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. Those not yet liberated I liberate. Those not yet awakened I awaken. Those not yet at peace I establish in peace. Those not yet entered into nirvana I guide to nirvana. I know both the present and the future as they truly are. I am the All-Knower, the All-Seer, the Knower of the Path, the Revealer of the Path, the Proclaimer of the Path. Come, all gods, humans, and asuras! Listen to the dharma.'"⁷

This proclamation echoes the Buddha's opening address in Chapter 1, but now the emphasis shifts from the fact of the Buddha's appearance to the universal inclusivity of the Buddha's teaching. The refrain "I am the Tathāgata" (我是如來) announces not personal identity but universal principle—the Buddha as the embodiment of enlightenment itself, available to all.⁸

The ten titles ascribed to the Buddha here are not ornamental but functional, each describing an aspect of enlightened understanding:⁹ - Worthy One (應供): deserving of reverence and support - Perfectly Enlightened One (正遍知): complete understanding of all dharmas - Knower of the World (世間解): understanding of how beings exist within reality - The All-Knower (一切知者): omniscience - The All-Seer (一切見者): non-dual perception - The Tamer of Beings (調御丈夫): guide to liberation

Each title describes facets of the same reality: complete understanding of the interdependent nature of all phenomena, and the capacity to guide other beings to that understanding.

⁷ Textual Variant [T.9.262, p.12]: The proclamation is repeated verbatim from Chapter 1, establishing textual continuity and suggesting the Buddha's consistent message despite varying contexts.

⁸ Philosophical Note [Cf. Process Theology]: This aligns with Whitehead's notion of God not as transcendent ruler but as the principle of persuasive transformation that operates within all becoming. The Buddha as "Tathāgata" (Thus-Gone-One) represents not personal deity but the structural principle of enlightenment available at all times and places.

⁹ Linguistic Note [Etymology]: The ten-fold epithet (十號) appears throughout the Lotus Sutra and Buddhist canon generally. These ten are considered comprehensive because they describe the Buddha's understanding (first four), authority (next four), and function (last two). The comprehensiveness suggests not arbitrary enumeration but systematic phenomenology of enlightenment.

## The Reception According to Capacity

The teaching then describes what occurs:

"At that time, countless millions of billions of beings come to the Buddha to hear the dharma. The Tathāgata observes these beings' faculties—whether sharp or dull, diligent or lazy—and teaches accordingly, in countless different ways, bringing all to joy and securing benefits for them.¹⁰
"These beings, hearing the dharma, find peace and happiness in the present life and are born in favorable realms in future lives. Through the path, they gain joy and continued opportunity to hear the dharma. Having heard it, they abandon obstacles and, to the extent of their ability, gradually enter the path. Thus, like that great cloud raining upon all forests and herbs and medicinal plants, with each receiving moisture according to its nature and becoming fully nourished and growing—so the Tathāgata's dharma rain causes all beings to grow."¹¹

Here we see the structure of Buddhist pedagogy: The Buddha observes (觀) the condition of beings, adapts (隨...說) the teaching to their condition, and allows them to gradually (漸) progress according to their nature. This is not haphazard but a precise responsiveness to actual conditions.¹²

The repetition of the cloud/rain metaphor establishes that we are not describing two different processes—one cosmic and one individual—but the same principle operating at all scales. The Buddha's teaching is like rain: universal, penetrating, responsive to the receiver's nature, gradual in its effects.

¹⁰ Philosophical Connection [Cf. Phenomenological Hermeneutics]: Gadamer's fusion of horizons (Horizontverschmelzung) describes understanding as the meeting of interpreter and text in their respective historicities. The Buddha's teaching method parallels this: the Buddha's wisdom meets beings' conditions, and understanding emerges from the encounter.

¹¹ Systems Theory Parallel [Homeostasis and Adaptation]: This describes what systems theorists call "equifinality"—the principle that diverse initial conditions can lead to similar end states through adaptive processes. Despite different starting points (dull vs. sharp faculties, lazy vs. diligent), all beings tend toward enlightenment through the dharma's influence.

¹² Contemporary Relevance [Trauma-Informed Teaching]: Modern therapeutic understanding recognizes that effective transformation requires meeting clients where they are, allowing autonomy in pacing, and avoiding re-traumatization through premature exposure to overwhelming truths. The Buddha's method described here anticipates these principles by millennia.

## The One-Taste Teaching and Differential Realization

The central paradox of this chapter now emerges explicitly:

"The Tathāgata's teaching has a single taste and aspect—namely, the taste of liberation, non-duality, and cessation, culminating in all-knowing wisdom. It ultimately reaches the realm of emptiness. Among beings who hear the Tathāgata's teaching, whether they uphold and recite it, read it, or practice it as taught, the merit they obtain is beyond their own awareness.¹³
"Why is this? Because only the Tathāgata knows the specific nature of each being—what it thinks upon, what it deliberates, in what manner it practices, through which dharma it thinks, deliberates, and practices, and through which dharma it attains which dharma. Beings dwell in countless different stations, and only the Tathāgata, seeing them as they truly are, perceives this without obstruction.¹⁴
"Just as medicinal herbs and trees do not themselves know whether their nature is superior, inferior, or middling, even so, the Tathāgata knows the single-taste dharma—the taste of liberation, non-duality, cessation, nirvana, the peace of final quiescence, ultimately reaching emptiness. Knowing this, the Tathāgata observes beings' desires and needs and protects them accordingly. Therefore, the Tathāgata does not immediately teach all-knowing wisdom to all beings."¹⁵

This passage crystallizes the central teaching. There is, ultimately, only one dharma—a single taste. Yet this single dharma manifests in infinitely varied forms according to the conditions of its reception.¹⁶ The Buddha's omniscience consists in knowing precisely which manifestation will meet each being where it actually stands.

This "one taste" is not bland uniformity but rather the fundamental principle underlying all differentiation. It is "the taste of liberation, non-duality, and cessation"—three ways of describing the same reality: - Liberation (解脫): freedom from conditioned existence - Non-duality (離相): absence of subject-object separation - Cessation (滅相): the ending of dualistic perception and its suffering

The phrase "ultimately reaching emptiness" (究竟涅槃常寂滅相，終歸於空) is especially significant. It suggests that beneath all phenomenal diversity lies emptiness (śūnyatā)—not as absence but as the absence of fixed, independent essence.¹⁷ All beings, all teachings, all phenomena ultimately resolve into this groundlessness, yet from this groundlessness, infinite forms emerge.¹⁸

¹³ Epistemological Note [Cf. Tacit Knowledge]: Polanyi's distinction between explicit and tacit knowledge parallels this point. Beings practice the dharma without full conscious understanding of its effects, yet the dharma produces transformation nonetheless. Enlightenment is not primarily intellectual but constitutive of being itself.

¹⁴ Omniscience [Redefined from Traditional Theism]: This description of Buddha-omniscience differs fundamentally from monotheistic conceptions. The Buddha's omniscience is not arbitrary or external but consists in perfect knowledge of causal relationships and the nature of beings. It is thereby knowable in principle to any being who awakens to the same understanding.

¹⁵ Pedagogical Principle: The Buddha's restraint in not immediately teaching all-knowing wisdom reflects a profound insight: Truth cannot be transferred directly but must be realized through each being's own investigation and gradual embodiment. This principle has implications for all teaching and communication.

¹⁶ Scientific Parallel [Quantum Field Theory]: In quantum field theory, the underlying reality is not particles but fields—oscillations in quantum fields. What we perceive as diverse particles are excitations of these universal fields under different conditions. Similarly, the Buddhist dharma is the universal field of interconnection, with all apparent beings as localized excitations of that field.

¹⁷ Philosophical Connection [Heideggerian Nothingness]: Heidegger's das Nichts (The Nothing) is not mere non-being but the ontological difference that allows being to emerge as manifest. Similarly, emptiness (śūnyatā) in Madhyamaka Buddhism is not annihilation but the non-substantiality that enables all phenomena to arise.

¹⁸ Cross-Reference [Ch. 2 - Skillful Means]: This completes the circle of Chapter 2's teaching. Skillful means are possible because of emptiness—because reality has no fixed essence and can manifest in infinite ways according to conditions. The dharma's flexibility is not weakness but an expression of its ultimate truth.

## The Assembly's Recognition

The Buddha then offers exceptional recognition to Mahākāśyapa and the assembly:

"Mahākāśyapa, you are rare and precious! You comprehend how the Tathāgata adapts teaching to circumstance. You are able to believe and accept it. Why? Because it is exceedingly difficult to understand and know the adaptive teachings of the Buddhas of the world."¹⁹

This recognition is crucial. Accepting the doctrine of skillful means is not simple. It requires understanding that truth is not violated by its adaptive expression, that emptiness allows infinite forms, and that received knowledge can be sufficient even when not total. Most beings resist this, preferring either absolutist certainty or total relativism.²⁰

¹⁹ Rhetorical Function: The Buddha's explicit praise of Mahākāśyapa and the assembly serves to validate their readiness to receive the more advanced teachings that follow in subsequent chapters.

²⁰ Philosophical Problem [Cf. Contemporary Epistemology]: The tension between epistemic humility (admitting the limits of our knowledge) and epistemic confidence (trusting that our understanding is adequate for practical purposes) is a central problem in contemporary philosophy of science. Buddhist epistemology resolves this by distinguishing the level of conventional truth (where specific teachings are adaptive and contextual) from ultimate truth (emptiness and interconnection).
