## The Revelation: The Sixteen Are Buddhas

Now comes an extraordinary revelation:

"The Buddha told the monks: 'These sixteen Bodhisattva-monks have long loved to teach the Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma. Each, in turn, has liberated six hundred million billion Gangetic-sand-numerous beings through this dharma, world after world, in successive rebirths, all being born together with the Bodhisattva and always hearing the dharma from him. By this cause and condition, these beings have encountered four hundred million billion Buddhas and yet do not exhaust the [Bodhisattva's] life-force, until the present day.'
"'Monks, I declare to you: these sixteen Bodhisattvas have now all attained supreme enlightenment and are at present teaching the dharma in all ten directions of the Buddha-lands, with immeasurable hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of Bodhisattvas and śrāvakas as their retinue.'"³³

This is the revelation. The sixteen young monks are not merely disciples—they are Buddhas themselves, currently teaching in all directions. The Buddha explicitly identifies himself among them:

"'Two Bodhisattvas are stationed in the eastern direction, teaching in Buddha-lands. Their names are Ākāśagarbha and Meru-Peak. In the southeastern direction, two are named Simha-Sound and Simha-Appearance. In the southern direction, two are named Sky-Dweller and Constant-Cessation. In the southwestern direction, two are named Imperial-Mark and Brahma-Mark. In the western direction, two are named Amitāyus and Relieving-All-Worlds'-Suffering. In the northwestern direction, two are named Tamalapatri-Sandalwood-Fragrance-Supernatural-Powers and Meru-Appearance. In the northern direction, two are named Cloud-Mastery and Cloud-Mastery-King. In the northeastern direction, one is named Destroying-All-Worlds'-Fear. The sixteenth is myself, Śākyamuni Buddha, in this Sahā-world, having attained Buddhahood.'"³⁴

The sixteen Bodhisattvas are now identified as Buddhas themselves—the same ones who will receive prophecies in the earlier chapters! This creates a stunning retro-active interpretation: what we read as chronologically earlier (Chapter 6's prophecies) is actually eternally true. The Buddha was always teaching the dharma; the prophecies are recognitions of what eternally is.³⁵

³³ Eternal Teaching [Omnipresent Buddha-Activity]: The revelation that the sixteen are already Buddhas teaching in all directions contradicts linear temporality. It suggests that the future is already present, that enlightenment is not sequential but eternally manifest.

³⁴ Śākyamuni's Identification [The Eternal Buddha]: The Buddha identifies himself as one of the sixteen—the sixteenth, specifically, teaching in the Sahā-world. This is extraordinary because it suggests that the individual historical Buddha is one manifestation of an eternal teaching principle.

³⁵ Prophetic Irony [Reinterpreting Past Teaching]: The prophecies in Chapter 6 are now revealed to be recognitions of eternal fact, not predictions of future events. The Buddha isn't promising something that will happen—the Buddha is recognizing what eternally happens.

## The Sixteen Disciples' Relation to Past Kalpas

The Buddha then reveals the ultimate purpose of this teaching:

"'Monks, I tell you: these sixteen Bodhisattvas, when they were young monks, taught the Lotus Sutra, and all beings who heard the dharma from them—you assembled monks today, and my future śrāvaka disciples after my extinction—are these very beings.
"'My disciples dwelling in the śrāvaka-path, to whom I teach supreme enlightenment—for these beings who are now in the position of being taught the Buddha-path, I am ever teaching them supreme enlightenment. Among those who do not hear this dharma, not comprehending the Bodhisattva-path, and who generate the notion of extinction regarding the nirvana they have attained, I shall cause them to enter nirvana. But in other Buddha-lands, seeking Buddha-wisdom, they shall hear this dharma, and only through the Buddha-vehicle shall they attain extinction—there is no other vehicle save the skillful means of the Tathāgata.'"³⁶

This passage contains the deepest revelation of the Phantom City parable's meaning. The Buddha explains:

1. Present disciples are ancient beings who heard the dharma from the sixteen Bodhisattvas eons ago 2. The Buddha continually teaches them toward Buddhahood, even if they haven't yet recognized it 3. Those who think they've reached extinction (nirvana) are actually resting at an intermediate stage 4. In other Buddha-lands, they will recognize that nirvana was skillful means 5. All will ultimately attain Buddhahood through the One Buddha Vehicle

This reveals that the Buddha's teaching is not sequential but cyclical and eternal—the same dharma continuously offered in different forms until beings are ready to understand its true nature.³⁷

³⁶ Cyclical Teaching [Eternal Offer]: The Buddha continuously teaches the dharma in different forms until beings are ready to receive the ultimate teaching. It's not that the teaching changes, but beings' capacity to receive it evolves.

³⁷ Nirvana as Intermediate Goal [Skillful Destination]: The crucial revelation: what appears as final achievement (nirvana) is actually a provisional resting place designed to refresh beings for the final journey to Buddhahood. The phantom city is now revealed.

## THE PHANTOM CITY PARABLE: The Central Teaching

The Buddha now tells the parable that illuminates all that has come before:

"'Monks, understand this through parable. There is a long and treacherous path five hundred yojanas in extent, full of dangers and fears, with few people, many wild beasts, and no water or herbs—a place that terrifies all beings. Suppose there are innumerable thousands of multitudes of people who wish to traverse this difficult path to reach a place of treasures.
'There is a wise and capable guide, skilled in the many paths, knowing well which ways are passable and which are blocked, who leads this multitude of people to traverse this difficult path. At the three-hundred-yojana mark, the people become exhausted and fearful, saying to the guide: "We are all weary and terrified. We are unable to go further. The path ahead is still distant. We wish to turn back."
'The guide, knowing these people can be saved and observing their fatigue and fear, thinks to himself with compassion: "These people are pitiable. How can they abandon the great treasure and wish to return?"
'The guide then employs skillful means, using his supernatural powers, creating an illusory city in the middle of this dangerous path. He tells the people: "Do not be afraid. Do not wish to return. Here is a great city where you may rest, having whatever you desire. If you are able to advance further to the treasure place, you may also go there."
'The exhausted people, hearing of this city, are greatly delighted and filled with joy, thinking to themselves: "We have been freed from this dangerous path and have gained peace and rest!"
'They enter this illusory city, thinking themselves to have reached their destination, resting securely within it. Then, knowing that these people have rested and are no longer weary, the guide causes the illusory city to vanish. He tells the people: "Come! The treasure place is near. This great city that I created was merely for your rest. I created it to allow you to cease your fatigue."'"³⁸

Now the parable's application:

"'Monks, the Tathāgata is like this guide. The Tathāgata is the great guide of all living beings. Knowing that all beings are attracted to and dwelling in the realms of birth and death, with suffering, anxiety, and fear on the difficult path of existence, the Buddha thinks: "If these beings merely hear the dharma of the One Buddha-Vehicle, they will not believe, accept, receive, or practice it, saying: 'The Buddha-path is long and distant, difficult to achieve.' Thus the Tathāgata employs skillful means, speaking of two kinds of nirvana.
'If living beings dwell in the two-vehicle path, thinking themselves to have attained extinction, to have reached the station of nirvana, the Tathāgata declares to them: 'What you have attained is not true extinction. Know that what you have attained is not the dharma-seat of enlightenment. In the One Buddha-Vehicle, I separate and distinguish the three vehicles. But all are just the Buddha's skillful means. Among these three vehicles, there is no actual existence of vehicles other than in appearance alone. Through these means, I am leading you to the Buddha-path.
'It is like the guide who created the city: having observed your fatigue and desires to rest, I taught you the dharma of the two vehicles as a provisional arrangement. Now understand: the treasure place is near. What I have taught is not the final teaching. Rather, through numberless skillful means, I am leading you toward the supreme vehicle, toward Buddha-wisdom, toward Buddha-knowledge, toward Buddha-insight.'"³⁹

This is the climax of the Lotus Sutra's theological revolution. The parable reveals:

1. The Buddha is a guide, not a distant deity 2. The three vehicles are skillful means, not different paths to different destinations 3. Nirvana is rest-station, not final goal 4. All beings are destined for Buddhahood, not some for enlightenment and some for lesser goals 5. The dharma is "one taste" manifesting in multiple forms according to beings' capacity 6. Skillful deception is compassionate guidance—the phantom city is not dishonest but wisely adapted to beings' current condition⁴⁰

The parable justifies everything the Buddha has done. The three vehicles are not lies but compassionate adaptations. Those who think they've reached nirvana are resting safely, not abandoned. And when they're ready, the final teaching is revealed.

³⁸ The Phantom City [Metaphor for Three Vehicles]: The illusory city represents the three vehicles (śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, Bodhisattva). They are not unreal in the conventional sense—travelers genuinely rest and are genuinely refreshed—but they are not the ultimate destination.

³⁹ Skillful Means Justified [Ethical Resolution]: The parable resolves the ethical question: Is the Buddha's teaching of the three vehicles deceptive? The answer: only from the perspective of ultimate truth. From the perspective of compassionate pedagogy, it is perfectly appropriate and justified.

⁴⁰ Provisional Teaching [Scaffolding Metaphor]: Like scaffolding that supports construction but must eventually be removed, skillful means support spiritual development but must eventually give way to ultimate truth. Yet the scaffolding is not false—it genuinely supports.

The Buddha then elaborates the parable in extended verse, emphasizing its cosmic significance:

"The Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Buddha
Sat ten kalpas at the enlightenment seat,
Yet the dharmas of Buddhahood did not appear.
Unable to attain supreme enlightenment,
Celestial beings and dragon-kings,
Asuras and other devas,
Rained celestial flowers as offerings,
Striking the celestial drums for ten kalpas,
Offering flowers to this Buddha,
Without pause until his extinction,
Celestial drums beat constantly,
And heavenly orchestras played without ceasing.
After ten kalpas passed,
The dharmas then appeared,
And enlightenment was attained. (lines 2167-2173)

The verse emphasizes the cosmic scale and the ten-kalpa delay. It then describes the assembly:

'Great Sage of incomparable worth!

## Summary: The Phantom City's Ultimate Meaning

Chapter 7 completes the doctrinal revolution begun in Chapter 2. If Chapter 2 established that skillful means exist, Chapter 7 now reveals their purpose and justification. The three vehicles are not different paths to different destinations but stages on a single path, with the phantom city representing the provisional achievement of nirvana.

This revelation requires complete reinterpretation of everything preceding it:

1. The Buddha's teaching of the three vehicles is not deceptive but compassionately adapted 2. The śrāvakas' nirvana is not final extinction but rest-and-refresh within the larger journey 3. The prophecies in Chapter 6 are not promises of future Buddhahood but recognitions of eternal truth 4. The present assembly consists of beings who have heard this dharma countless times across countless lifetimes 5. The Lotus Sutra itself is the final revelation of what was always taught

The parable accomplishes what previous teaching could not: it transforms intellectual understanding into emotional-intuitive recognition. Readers feel the weariness of the travelers, the joy of finding the city, the shock of learning it's illusory, and the gratitude for the guide's compassion.

This emotional-narrative pedagogy itself exemplifies skillful means: the Buddha uses the form that reaches hearts, not merely minds.

## Consequences and Implications

For understanding the three vehicles: They are not unequal or inferior paths but provisional destinations. A śrāvaka who practices well achieves real rest and benefit; it's just not the ultimate destination. For understanding the Buddha: The Buddha is revealed as guide (導師) rather than distant deity. The Buddha observes, knows conditions, adapts teaching, ensures beings advance according to capacity. For understanding enlightenment: It is not monopoly of rare individuals but destiny of all beings. Every being has encountered this teaching, rests in provisional achievements, and is guided toward ultimate awakening. For understanding the dharma: It is singular in taste yet infinite in expression. Like rain falling equally yet nourishing different plants differently, the dharma reaches all beings yet produces differentiated realization according to each being's nature. For understanding practice: It need not be harsh or extreme. The guide allows travelers to rest in the phantom city; rest is real and necessary. Only when rested can they continue. This compassionate recognition of beings' limits is itself the dharma.

The Ancient Buddha: Vast Span of Time

The Buddha begins with an extraordinary temporal introduction:

"The Buddha told the monks: 'Incalculably long ago, beyond a boundless and inconceivable number of immeasurable aeons, there was a Buddha named Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Tathāgata, Worthy One, Perfectly Enlightened One, Possessor of Luminous Conduct, Well-Gone One, Knower of the World, Unsurpassed One, Tamer of Beings, Teacher of Gods and Humans, Buddha, World-Honored One. His Buddha-land was called "Realm of Good Form." The kalpa was named "Great Imagery."
'Monks, from the time of that Buddha's final nirvana until now, a very long time has passed. To illustrate: Suppose someone took all the earth of the threefold thousand-fold great thousand-world system and ground it into ink. Then, passing through the east for a thousand Buddha-lands, he would place a single dot of ink-dust. He would continue in this way throughout all the earth-ink, placing dots. Tell me: What do you think? Can a calculator or a calculator's apprentice possibly determine the extent of these Buddha-lands, either those marked with ink or those left unmarked?'
The monks replied: 'No, World-Honored One.'²
The Buddha said: 'All those Buddha-lands, whether marked or unmarked, if ground into dust—one dust-particle equals one kalpa—the Buddha Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory, from his final nirvana until now, has surpassed even this number by immeasurable, boundless, hundreds of thousands of millions of aeons. Yet through the power of the Tathāgata's knowledge and vision, I observe that ancient time as though it were the present day.'"³

This opening establishes an almost incomprehensible temporal scale. The point is not mere chronological vastness but metaphysical significance: the Buddha can perceive time itself directly, seeing past and future as a single present reality. This prefigures the revelation in Chapter 16 that the Buddha's enlightenment is eternal and omnipresent.⁴

The mathematical procedure—grinding all earth into ink, using each grain to mark Buddha-lands, then converting Buddha-lands into aeons—is extraordinary. It converts space into substance (earth to ink), then uses that substance to measure space (Buddha-lands), then converts the result into time (aeons). The rhetoric suggests that space, substance, and time are ultimately convertible—different dimensions of a single underlying reality.⁵

² Mathematical Humility [Epistemological Significance]: The monks' answer "No, World-Honored One" expresses that some quantities exceed all calculation. This establishes that true enlightenment involves recognizing the limits of quantification and rationality—a point that will become significant in understanding the dharma.

³ Buddha's Direct Perception [Omniscience Redefined]: The assertion that the Buddha "observes that ancient time as though it were the present day" indicates that enlightenment involves transcending the temporal flow rather than merely acquiring more information. The Buddha doesn't remember the past—the Buddha perceives it directly in present awareness.

⁴ Cross-Reference [Ch. 16 - Eternal Buddha]: This cosmic time-scale foreshadows Chapter 16's revelation that the Buddha's enlightenment is not a past event but an eternal present, continuously happening, continuously teaching.

⁵ Philosophical Implication [Dimensions of Reality]: The equivalence of space, substance, and time in the calculation suggests that these are not fundamental categories but conventional ways of organizing experience—a insight consistent with contemporary physics.

## The Buddha's Long Path to Enlightenment

The narrative then describes an extraordinary event:

"The Buddha told the monks: 'Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory, when first sitting at the Bodhisattva-tree, having defeated the armies of Māra, was on the verge of attaining anuttara-samyak-sambodhi (supreme enlightenment), yet the dharmas of all Buddhas did not manifest before him. Thus he sat in full lotus position, his body and mind unmoved, for one small kalpa—and up to ten small kalpas—yet still the dharmas did not appear before him.'⁶
'At that time, the gods of Trāyastriṃśa heaven first spread a lion-seat beneath the Bodhisattva-tree, high one yojana. The Buddha would attain supreme enlightenment upon this seat. As soon as he sat upon it, the Brahmā-kings rained celestial flowers, covering the earth a hundred yojanas. The divine fragrance came in gentle breezes, blowing away the withered flowers and raining down fresh ones continuously for ten small kalpas, supplying the Buddha. Even until his final nirvana, the flowers constantly rained down. The Four Kings of the cardinal directions struck celestial drums to honor the Buddha. The remaining gods created celestial music, continuing for ten small kalpas until his final nirvana, likewise.'⁷

This extraordinary passage deserves careful attention. Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory sits for ten kalpas after defeating Māra but before attaining enlightenment. This is not lack of power but deliberate pause—the dharmas "did not manifest" not because he couldn't access them but because something more was required.⁸

What is this delay? The text suggests that enlightenment itself is not primarily cognitive acquisition but the manifestation of something already present. The Buddha-dharmas must "appear" or "manifest" (現在前)—they don't need to be created or obtained but revealed or recognized as always-already present.⁹

The continuous celestial rain of flowers for ten kalpas—and continuing even after enlightenment until the Buddha's nirvana—is significant. It suggests that the support of all cosmic forces continues throughout the Buddha's entire existence, not just at enlightenment. This hints at the teaching that will be revealed in Chapter 16: the Buddha's enlightenment is not an event in time but an eternal presence.

⁶ The Buddha's Struggle [Humanizing Enlightenment]: The image of the Buddha sitting for ten kalpas without attaining enlightenment is striking. It suggests that enlightenment is not automatically granted even to those who have done everything correctly. There is a dimension of patience, waiting, trust that cannot be bypassed even by the Buddha.

⁷ Celestial Support [Cosmic Significance]: The entire cosmos celebrates and supports the Buddha's enlightenment. This suggests that enlightenment is not individual achievement but a cosmic event in which all forces participate.

⁸ Dharmas as Manifestation [Ontological Point]: The phrasing "dharmas did not manifest" suggests that Buddhas don't create or invent the dharmas but recognize and manifest what is eternally true. This is consistent with the teaching that the dharma is not a doctrine but the nature of reality itself.

⁹ Ontological Readiness [The Buddha's Receptivity]: What changes during the ten-kalpa wait is not cosmic conditions but the Buddha's own readiness to manifest what is eternally present. This suggests that enlightenment requires not acquisition but receptivity, not creation but recognition.

## The Sixteen Sons: From Princes to Monks

The Buddha then describes a crucial turning point:

"After ten small kalpas, the Buddha's dharmas manifested before him, and he attained supreme enlightenment.¹⁰ This Buddha, before renouncing the world, had sixteen sons. Upon hearing that their father had attained supreme enlightenment, they all abandoned their precious possessions and went to the Buddha's presence. Their mothers wept as they accompanied them. Their grandfather, the wheel-turning monarch, together with one hundred great ministers and hundreds of thousands of millions of multitudes, all surrounded them and accompanied them to the place of enlightenment.¹¹
'All wished to draw near to Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Tathāgata, to make offerings and show reverence, honor, and praise. Upon arriving, they prostrated their heads to his feet, circumambulated him, then standing with palms joined gazed upon the World-Honored One and praised him in verse:
"Great Mighty World-Honored One,
For the sake of liberating all beings,
Through immeasurable billions of aeons,
You have at last attained Buddhahood.
Your vows all fulfilled, supremely auspicious and fortunate,
The World-Honored One is most rare and precious!
In a single sitting for ten small kalpas,
Your body, hands, and feet remained still and unmoved.
Your mind was ever peaceful and equanimous,
Never scattered or distracted,
Ultimately dwelling in ultimate peace,
Abiding in the dharma without outflows.
Now seeing the World-Honored One,
Safely established in enlightenment,
We have gained great benefit,
And we celebrate with immense joy!"¹²

The sixteen sons are crucial figures. They represent a generation that follows the Buddha's enlightenment, yet they also represent the disciples of the future (as will be revealed). Their abandonment of precious possessions parallels the disciples' renunciation in Chapter 4's Prodigal Son parable.

¹⁰ The Buddha's Manifestation [Sudden Appearance]: After ten kalpas of waiting, the dharmas "manifest before him" suddenly. The passage suggests that enlightenment, when it comes, is sudden—not gradual accumulation but recognition.

¹¹ The Buddha's Human Family [Contextualization]: Mentioning the Buddha's sixteen sons grounds his enlightenment in a relational context. He is not an isolated saint but one who awakened within relationships, in the midst of a family, a kingdom, a cosmos.

¹² Filial Rejoicing [Relational Recognition]: The sons recognize their father's attainment and rejoice. This models how enlightenment in one person awakens recognition in others, particularly those closest to the awakened one.

## The Request to Teach: The Dharma-Wheel Turns

The narrative continues:

"At that time, the sixteen prince-sons, having praised the Buddha in verse, urged the World-Honored One to turn the dharma-wheel, saying: 'The World-Honored One's teaching brings much peace, compassion, benefit, and advantage to all gods and humans.' Again, they spoke in verse:
"O Mighty World-Honored One,
Incomparable and unequaled,
Adorned with a hundred auspices,
Possessor of supreme wisdom!
We beseech you to teach the world,
Liberating us and all beings,
Revealing and displaying this wisdom,
So that all may attain it.
If we and all beings attain Buddhahood,
The World-Honored One, knowing the depths of beings' minds,
Understanding their paths and their wisdom,
Their desires and their merit, their karmic deeds—
World-Honored One, knowing all these,
Turn the wheel of unsurpassed dharma!'"¹³

The princes' request is for the Buddha to teach the dharma more broadly—to "turn the dharma-wheel" (轉法輪). This is the traditional Buddhist term for the Buddha's proclamation of the dharma.

What's significant here is that the sons explicitly request that "we and all beings attain Buddhahood"—they are not asking for personal advancement but for universal enlightenment. This anticipates the ultimate teaching of the Lotus Sutra: all beings are destined for Buddhahood.

The Buddha accepts their request silently (默然許之), indicating readiness without elaborate ceremony. His silence conveys assent and appropriate restraint.

¹³ Universal Aspiration [The Sons' Vision]: The sons' request is not for personal benefit but for universal Buddhahood of all beings. This universal orientation will be rewarded—they themselves will become the Buddhas described in the final revelation.

## The Buddha's Teaching: Cosmic Illumination

The narrative describes the cosmic impact of the Buddha's enlightenment and teaching:

"When the Buddha Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory attained supreme enlightenment, the worlds in all ten directions—each with five hundred million billion Buddha-lands—underwent sixfold trembling. In the dark and shadowy places of these Buddha-lands, places that the light of the sun and moon could not reach, there was suddenly great luminosity. The beings dwelling there could each see one another and said: 'How is it that beings suddenly appeared here?' And in that Buddha-realm, the celestial palaces, even up to the Brahma-palaces, all underwent sixfold trembling, and great light pervaded all worlds, surpassing the light of the celestial beings."¹⁴

This describes the cosmic significance of the Buddha's enlightenment. The "sixfold trembling" (六種震動) is a traditional Buddhist metaphor for cosmic transformation—earth trembles, trembles and sways, trembles and shakes, becomes fragrant, and becomes bright. This indicates that enlightenment is not private spiritual achievement but cosmic event affecting all dimensions of existence.¹⁵

¹⁴ Enlightenment as Cosmic Event [Metaphysical Significance]: The Buddha's enlightenment is described not as personal realization but as a cosmic transformation. This suggests that enlightenment is simultaneously individual and universal, particular and cosmic.

¹⁵ Light Replacing Darkness [Epistemological Illumination]: The places previously dark—"places that the light of the sun and moon could not reach"—now become luminous. This metaphorically suggests that enlightenment illuminates what was previously hidden or incomprehensible.

## The Brahmas' Discovery and Praise

The Buddha continues describing how celestial beings from all ten directions recognize the light and come to investigate:

"At that time, from the eastern direction, from five hundred million billion Buddha-lands, in the Brahma-palaces of those celestial realms, the light from their dwellings shone brightly and brilliantly, more radiant than usual. The Brahma-kings, each pondering: 'For what reason does this unprecedented brightness illuminate our palaces?' immediately departed and met together to discuss this matter.¹⁶
"Among them was a great Brahma-king named 'Savior of All,' who spoke to the gathered Brahmas: 'Our heavenly palaces, which never before possessed such light, have now illuminated unexpectedly. This cannot be without cause. Let us together investigate the cause. Is it a great and virtuous being born? Is a Buddha appearing in the world? This great light pervades all directions.'¹⁷
"Then five hundred million billion Brahma-kings, together with their palaces, each took celestial flowers in their robes and jointly traveled westward, seeking the source of this light. They saw Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Tathāgata, dwelling at the place of enlightenment, beneath the Bodhisattva-tree, seated on a lion-throne, with gods, dragon-kings, gandharvas, kiṃnaras, mahoragas, humans and non-humans, all reverently surrounding him. They also saw the sixteen prince-sons requesting the Buddha to turn the dharma-wheel."¹⁸

The Brahma-kings recognize that the light indicates something extraordinary and seek its source. This models how enlightenment radiates outward, attracting beings of all kinds. The description of the Brahmas presenting their heavenly palaces as offerings suggests their complete surrender and devotion.

¹⁶ Cosmic Communication [Light as Signal]: The light acts as a cosmic signal—beings instantly recognize that something momentous has occurred. This suggests that enlightenment creates a radiation of truth that attracts those ready to receive it.

¹⁷ Brahma's Question [Epistemological Readiness]: The Brahma-king's question "Is a Buddha appearing in the world?" shows that beings recognize the possibility of enlightenment—they have categories and expectations that prepare them to recognize enlightenment when it appears.

¹⁸ Multi-Directional Witness [Universal Recognition]: The Brahmas from all ten directions make identical journeys and discoveries, suggesting that enlightenment is simultaneously apparent from multiple perspectives—it is objectively real, not subjective interpretation.

## The Dharma-Teaching: Dependent Origination

The Buddha then describes what dharma Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory taught:

"At that time, the Buddha Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory, receiving the requests of the Brahma-kings and the sixteen prince-sons, immediately turned the dharma-wheel three times with twelve aspects, that which no śramaṇa, brahmin, god, māra, or brahma in the world could turn, namely:¹⁹
'This is suffering, this is its arising, this is its cessation, this is the path leading to its cessation.'
"And he extensively explained the dharma of the twelve-fold dependent origination:²⁰
'Ignorance conditions formation;
Formation conditions consciousness;
Consciousness conditions name-and-form;
Name-and-form conditions the six sense-bases;
The six sense-bases condition contact;
Contact conditions feeling;
Feeling conditions craving;
Craving conditions grasping;
Grasping conditions existence;
Existence conditions birth;
Birth conditions old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, grief, and despair.
"And: Ignorance ceasing, formation ceases; formation ceasing, consciousness ceases; consciousness ceasing, name-and-form ceases; name-and-form ceasing, the six sense-bases cease; the six sense-bases ceasing, contact ceases; contact ceasing, feeling ceases; feeling ceasing, craving ceases; craving ceasing, grasping ceases; grasping ceasing, existence ceases; existence ceasing, birth ceases; birth ceasing, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, grief, and despair cease."²¹

This foundational teaching of dependent origination (pratītyasamutpāda) is presented as the central dharma that Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory teaches. It is "that which no śramaṇa, brahmin, god, māra, or brahma in the world could turn"—it is beyond the reach of any limited being, yet the Buddha proclaims it.²²

The teaching describes how suffering arises through interdependent conditions and how suffering ceases when those conditions are dissolved. This is the fundamental insight of Buddhism: that suffering is not intrinsic but conditional, and therefore can be ended through understanding and transforming conditions.²³

The "three times with twelve aspects" refers to teaching the four truths (suffering, its origin, its cessation, the path) three times over, with each teaching having twelve aspects (the four truths taught forward, backward, and showing causality both ways).

¹⁹ The Dharma-Wheel [Metaphor for Teaching]: Turning the dharma-wheel is the traditional Buddhist metaphor for teaching. Like a physical wheel that transforms energy into motion, the dharma-wheel transforms understanding into liberation.

²⁰ Dependent Origination [The Core Buddhist Insight]: Dependent origination (pratītyasamutpāda) is Buddhism's fundamental insight into how suffering arises. It is "the middle way" between eternalism (suffering is intrinsic) and nihilism (suffering is meaningless). Suffering is real but conditional, and therefore transformable.

²¹ Causal Reversal [Cessation Process]: The listing of dependent origination in reverse (cessation rather than arising) shows the symmetry of the process. If the forward chain explains suffering's origin, the reverse chain explains its cessation. This mathematical symmetry suggests deep truth.

²² Beyond All Beings [Transcendence of Teaching]: The assertion that the dharma "no being in the world could turn" emphasizes that this is not human philosophy or logic but truth that transcends all limited perspectives. Yet it is the Buddha who enunciates it—suggesting the Buddha's unique capacityto bridge transcendent truth and human language.

²³ Conditionality as Liberation [Key Insight]: The crucial insight is that if suffering arises through conditions, then by understanding and transforming conditions, suffering ceases. This is the basis for Buddhist praxis.

## The Assembly's Realization: From Many to All

The Buddha then describes the impact of this teaching:

"When the Buddha taught this dharma in the assembly of gods and humans, six hundred million billion nayutas of beings, through not-grasping of all dharmas, attained liberation from all outflows, achieved deep, subtle meditative absorption, the three knowledges, and the six supernatural powers, and perfected the eight liberations.²⁴
"In the second and third turnings of the dharma-wheel, thousands of millions of Gangetic-sand-numerous nayutas of beings, likewise through not-grasping of all dharmas, attained liberation from all outflows.²⁵
"From then onward, the assembly of śrāvakas became immeasurable and boundless, beyond counting."²⁶

The teaching produces immediate and massive results. Beings attain liberation through the teaching of dependent origination. Notice the phrase "through not-grasping of all dharmas"—liberation comes not through acquiring something but through releasing all fixed views and attachments.

The progression is significant: first teaching produces six hundred million billion Nayuta beings liberated; second teaching produces thousands of millions of times more; "from then onward" the numbers become incalculable. This suggests that enlightenment radiates outward—each being who awakens becomes a teaching for others, creating exponential growth.

²⁴ Not-Grasping as Liberation [Key Practice]: The phrase "through not-grasping of all dharmas" is crucial. Liberation comes through releasing, not acquiring. This inverts the typical human strategy of accumulation.

²⁵ The Three Knowledges: (1) Knowledge of past lives, (2) knowledge of beings' death and rebirth, (3) knowledge of destruction of outflows. These represent complete understanding of causal processes and the end of ignorance.

²⁶ Exponential Growth [Cascading Enlightenment]: The numbers grow with each teaching—not simply accumulating but multiplying. This suggests that enlightenment has momentum—each awakened being awakens others.

## The Sixteen Sons Request the Great Vehicle Teaching

The narrative then takes a crucial turn:

"At that time, the sixteen prince-sons, having become the Buddha's disciples through their own choice, all became monks with keen faculties, bright wisdom, and having previously made offerings to hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of Buddhas, now practicing pure conduct, seeking supreme enlightenment. The sixteen sons together said to the Buddha: 'World-Honored One, the immeasurable thousands of millions of billions of great virtue and accomplished śrāvakas have now all been fulfilled. World-Honored One, you should also teach us the dharma of supreme enlightenment. We desire to study it after hearing it. World-Honored One, we and our retinues all wish to attain Buddhahood just as you have, possessing the pure wisdom-eye like the World-Honored One.'
"The Buddha, knowing the sixteen youths' hearts, the conduct of their past lives, understanding their deep wishes—what they contemplated, what they meditated upon, for what purposes they meditated—spoke to them using limitless causes and conditions, countless parables, and the six perfections and supernatural powers, distinguishing the true dharma, the Bodhisattva-path, teaching the Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma, in verses as numerous as the sands of the Ganges."²⁷

This is a turning point. After establishing the foundation (the four truths and dependent origination), the Buddha now teaches the Great Vehicle dharma to those ready for it. The sixteen sons request the teaching explicitly, expressing their intention to attain Buddhahood, not just nirvana.

The Buddha's response "knowing the sixteen youths' hearts, the conduct of their past lives" echoes the Medicinal Herbs teaching: the Buddha's pedagogy is responsive to beings' actual conditions. He teaches them "using limitless causes and conditions, countless parables"—the very methods employed in the Lotus Sutra itself.²⁸

²⁷ The Great Vehicle Request [The Next Stage]: The sons request specifically the dharma of supreme enlightenment—not the four truths but the Bodhisattva path. The Buddha first establishes the foundation with śrāvakas, then teaches the advanced teaching to those ready for it.

²⁸ Meta-Textual Reference [The Sutra Refers to Itself]: The text explicitly says the Buddha taught the Lotus Sutra in verses—the very text we are reading. This creates an identity between the ancient teaching and the present text, suggesting the teaching's eternal present-ness.

## The Buddha's Deepening Practice: Extended Meditation

A crucial transition now occurs:

"After the Buddha had taught this dharma, he entered a quiet chamber, abode in meditative absorption, sitting in a single place for eighty-four thousand kalpas.²⁹
"At that time, the sixteen Bodhisattva-monks, knowing that the Buddha had entered his chamber and was sitting in profound meditation, each ascended a dharma-seat and also taught the Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma, speaking the unsurpassed wisdom to immeasurable billions of multitudes, for eighty-four thousand kalpas, each liberating six hundred million billion Gangetic-sand-numerous nayutas of beings, causing them to generate the aspiration for supreme enlightenment.³⁰
"Upon the Buddha's emergence from meditation after eighty-four thousand kalpas, he went to the dharma-seat, sat serenely, and spoke to the great assembly: 'These sixteen Bodhisattva-monks are most rare and precious. Their faculties are keen and their wisdom bright. They have previously made offerings to immeasurable thousands of millions of billions of Buddhas. At the Buddha-lands of the Buddhas, they constantly practiced pure conduct, bearing the Buddha-wisdom, and opening up and displaying dharma to all beings, causing them to enter therein.'"³¹

This extraordinary passage describes the Buddha entering meditation for eighty-four thousand kalpas—an almost incomprehensible duration—while the sixteen monk-Bodhisattvas teach the dharma to vast multitudes in his stead.

The significance is profound: the Buddha does not monopolize teaching but empowers others to teach in his absence. The sixteen Bodhisattvas, each teaching for eighty-four thousand kalpas, each liberating incalculable multitudes, represent enlightenment spreading through a network of awakened beings rather than depending on a single teacher.³²

This model of distributed teaching prefigures the Bodhisattva ideal developed in later chapters: enlightenment is not solitary achievement but collaborative transformation, with awakened beings continually awakening others.

²⁹ Extended Meditation [Transcendence of Time]: The Buddha's eighty-four thousand kalpa meditation parallels the ten kalpas he spent waiting for enlightenment at the beginning of the chapter. Both suggest that enlightenment involves periods of deep interiority and receptivity beyond ordinary consciousness.

³⁰ Collaborative Teaching [Network Enlightenment]: Rather than the Buddha teaching everyone personally, he empowers other enlightened beings to teach. This is the model of the Bodhisattva community: networks of awakened beings continually awakening others.

³¹ Exponential Multiplication [Teaching's Growth]: Each of the sixteen Bodhisattvas teaches millions of billions of beings over eighty-four thousand kalpas. Multiply sixteen by these numbers, and the scale of enlightenment becomes cosmic.

³² Future Reference [Anticipating Later Teachings]: This passage establishes a principle that will be central in later chapters: enlightenment spreads through networks of awakened beings, not through individual heroes. This is the Bodhisattva path's relational vision of awakening.

## The Revelation: The Sixteen Are Buddhas

Now comes an extraordinary revelation:

"The Buddha told the monks: 'These sixteen Bodhisattva-monks have long loved to teach the Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma. Each, in turn, has liberated six hundred million billion Gangetic-sand-numerous beings through this dharma, world after world, in successive rebirths, all being born together with the Bodhisattva and always hearing the dharma from him. By this cause and condition, these beings have encountered four hundred million billion Buddhas and yet do not exhaust the [Bodhisattva's] life-force, until the present day.'
"'Monks, I declare to you: these sixteen Bodhisattvas have now all attained supreme enlightenment and are at present teaching the dharma in all ten directions of the Buddha-lands, with immeasurable hundreds of thousands of millions of billions of Bodhisattvas and śrāvakas as their retinue.'"³³

This is the revelation. The sixteen young monks are not merely disciples—they are Buddhas themselves, currently teaching in all directions. The Buddha explicitly identifies himself among them:

"'Two Bodhisattvas are stationed in the eastern direction, teaching in Buddha-lands. Their names are Ākāśagarbha and Meru-Peak. In the southeastern direction, two are named Simha-Sound and Simha-Appearance. In the southern direction, two are named Sky-Dweller and Constant-Cessation. In the southwestern direction, two are named Imperial-Mark and Brahma-Mark. In the western direction, two are named Amitāyus and Relieving-All-Worlds'-Suffering. In the northwestern direction, two are named Tamalapatri-Sandalwood-Fragrance-Supernatural-Powers and Meru-Appearance. In the northern direction, two are named Cloud-Mastery and Cloud-Mastery-King. In the northeastern direction, one is named Destroying-All-Worlds'-Fear. The sixteenth is myself, Śākyamuni Buddha, in this Sahā-world, having attained Buddhahood.'"³⁴

The sixteen Bodhisattvas are now identified as Buddhas themselves—the same ones who will receive prophecies in the earlier chapters! This creates a stunning retro-active interpretation: what we read as chronologically earlier (Chapter 6's prophecies) is actually eternally true. The Buddha was always teaching the dharma; the prophecies are recognitions of what eternally is.³⁵

³³ Eternal Teaching [Omnipresent Buddha-Activity]: The revelation that the sixteen are already Buddhas teaching in all directions contradicts linear temporality. It suggests that the future is already present, that enlightenment is not sequential but eternally manifest.

³⁴ Śākyamuni's Identification [The Eternal Buddha]: The Buddha identifies himself as one of the sixteen—the sixteenth, specifically, teaching in the Sahā-world. This is extraordinary because it suggests that the individual historical Buddha is one manifestation of an eternal teaching principle.

³⁵ Prophetic Irony [Reinterpreting Past Teaching]: The prophecies in Chapter 6 are now revealed to be recognitions of eternal fact, not predictions of future events. The Buddha isn't promising something that will happen—the Buddha is recognizing what eternally happens.

## The Sixteen Disciples' Relation to Past Kalpas

The Buddha then reveals the ultimate purpose of this teaching:

"'Monks, I tell you: these sixteen Bodhisattvas, when they were young monks, taught the Lotus Sutra, and all beings who heard the dharma from them—you assembled monks today, and my future śrāvaka disciples after my extinction—are these very beings.
"'My disciples dwelling in the śrāvaka-path, to whom I teach supreme enlightenment—for these beings who are now in the position of being taught the Buddha-path, I am ever teaching them supreme enlightenment. Among those who do not hear this dharma, not comprehending the Bodhisattva-path, and who generate the notion of extinction regarding the nirvana they have attained, I shall cause them to enter nirvana. But in other Buddha-lands, seeking Buddha-wisdom, they shall hear this dharma, and only through the Buddha-vehicle shall they attain extinction—there is no other vehicle save the skillful means of the Tathāgata.'"³⁶

This passage contains the deepest revelation of the Phantom City parable's meaning. The Buddha explains:

1. Present disciples are ancient beings who heard the dharma from the sixteen Bodhisattvas eons ago 2. The Buddha continually teaches them toward Buddhahood, even if they haven't yet recognized it 3. Those who think they've reached extinction (nirvana) are actually resting at an intermediate stage 4. In other Buddha-lands, they will recognize that nirvana was skillful means 5. All will ultimately attain Buddhahood through the One Buddha Vehicle

This reveals that the Buddha's teaching is not sequential but cyclical and eternal—the same dharma continuously offered in different forms until beings are ready to understand its true nature.³⁷

³⁶ Cyclical Teaching [Eternal Offer]: The Buddha continuously teaches the dharma in different forms until beings are ready to receive the ultimate teaching. It's not that the teaching changes, but beings' capacity to receive it evolves.

³⁷ Nirvana as Intermediate Goal [Skillful Destination]: The crucial revelation: what appears as final achievement (nirvana) is actually a provisional resting place designed to refresh beings for the final journey to Buddhahood. The phantom city is now revealed.

## THE PHANTOM CITY PARABLE: The Central Teaching

The Buddha now tells the parable that illuminates all that has come before:

"'Monks, understand this through parable. There is a long and treacherous path five hundred yojanas in extent, full of dangers and fears, with few people, many wild beasts, and no water or herbs—a place that terrifies all beings. Suppose there are innumerable thousands of multitudes of people who wish to traverse this difficult path to reach a place of treasures.
'There is a wise and capable guide, skilled in the many paths, knowing well which ways are passable and which are blocked, who leads this multitude of people to traverse this difficult path. At the three-hundred-yojana mark, the people become exhausted and fearful, saying to the guide: "We are all weary and terrified. We are unable to go further. The path ahead is still distant. We wish to turn back."
'The guide, knowing these people can be saved and observing their fatigue and fear, thinks to himself with compassion: "These people are pitiable. How can they abandon the great treasure and wish to return?"
'The guide then employs skillful means, using his supernatural powers, creating an illusory city in the middle of this dangerous path. He tells the people: "Do not be afraid. Do not wish to return. Here is a great city where you may rest, having whatever you desire. If you are able to advance further to the treasure place, you may also go there."
'The exhausted people, hearing of this city, are greatly delighted and filled with joy, thinking to themselves: "We have been freed from this dangerous path and have gained peace and rest!"
'They enter this illusory city, thinking themselves to have reached their destination, resting securely within it. Then, knowing that these people have rested and are no longer weary, the guide causes the illusory city to vanish. He tells the people: "Come! The treasure place is near. This great city that I created was merely for your rest. I created it to allow you to cease your fatigue."'"³⁸

Now the parable's application:

"'Monks, the Tathāgata is like this guide. The Tathāgata is the great guide of all living beings. Knowing that all beings are attracted to and dwelling in the realms of birth and death, with suffering, anxiety, and fear on the difficult path of existence, the Buddha thinks: "If these beings merely hear the dharma of the One Buddha-Vehicle, they will not believe, accept, receive, or practice it, saying: 'The Buddha-path is long and distant, difficult to achieve.' Thus the Tathāgata employs skillful means, speaking of two kinds of nirvana.
'If living beings dwell in the two-vehicle path, thinking themselves to have attained extinction, to have reached the station of nirvana, the Tathāgata declares to them: 'What you have attained is not true extinction. Know that what you have attained is not the dharma-seat of enlightenment. In the One Buddha-Vehicle, I separate and distinguish the three vehicles. But all are just the Buddha's skillful means. Among these three vehicles, there is no actual existence of vehicles other than in appearance alone. Through these means, I am leading you to the Buddha-path.
'It is like the guide who created the city: having observed your fatigue and desires to rest, I taught you the dharma of the two vehicles as a provisional arrangement. Now understand: the treasure place is near. What I have taught is not the final teaching. Rather, through numberless skillful means, I am leading you toward the supreme vehicle, toward Buddha-wisdom, toward Buddha-knowledge, toward Buddha-insight.'"³⁹

This is the climax of the Lotus Sutra's theological revolution. The parable reveals:

1. The Buddha is a guide, not a distant deity 2. The three vehicles are skillful means, not different paths to different destinations 3. Nirvana is rest-station, not final goal 4. All beings are destined for Buddhahood, not some for enlightenment and some for lesser goals 5. The dharma is "one taste" manifesting in multiple forms according to beings' capacity 6. Skillful deception is compassionate guidance—the phantom city is not dishonest but wisely adapted to beings' current condition⁴⁰

The parable justifies everything the Buddha has done. The three vehicles are not lies but compassionate adaptations. Those who think they've reached nirvana are resting safely, not abandoned. And when they're ready, the final teaching is revealed.

³⁸ The Phantom City [Metaphor for Three Vehicles]: The illusory city represents the three vehicles (śrāvaka, pratyekabuddha, Bodhisattva). They are not unreal in the conventional sense—travelers genuinely rest and are genuinely refreshed—but they are not the ultimate destination.

³⁹ Skillful Means Justified [Ethical Resolution]: The parable resolves the ethical question: Is the Buddha's teaching of the three vehicles deceptive? The answer: only from the perspective of ultimate truth. From the perspective of compassionate pedagogy, it is perfectly appropriate and justified.

⁴⁰ Provisional Teaching [Scaffolding Metaphor]: Like scaffolding that supports construction but must eventually be removed, skillful means support spiritual development but must eventually give way to ultimate truth. Yet the scaffolding is not false—it genuinely supports.

---

## The Verse Elaboration: Cosmic Echoes

The Buddha then elaborates the parable in extended verse, emphasizing its cosmic significance:

"The Great Penetrating Wisdom Victory Buddha
Sat ten kalpas at the enlightenment seat,
Yet the dharmas of Buddhahood did not appear.
Unable to attain supreme enlightenment,
Celestial beings and dragon-kings,
Asuras and other devas,
Rained celestial flowers as offerings,
Striking the celestial drums for ten kalpas,
Offering flowers to this Buddha,
Without pause until his extinction,
Celestial drums beat constantly,
And heavenly orchestras played without ceasing.
After ten kalpas passed,
The dharmas then appeared,
And enlightenment was attained. (lines 2167-2173)

The verse emphasizes the cosmic scale and the ten-kalpa delay. It then describes the assembly:

"The sixteen sons of the Buddha,
Each with retinues of thousands of millions,
All came to the Buddha with palms joined,
And requested the dharma-wheel's turning. (lines 2175-2176)
'Great Sage of incomparable worth!
May you transform all beings,
Shake and awaken all the world,
For all recognize the assembly's calling. (lines 2177-2179)
The celestial devas' palaces
Shone with previously unseen light,
And the Brahmā-kings came to the Buddha
Bearing flowers in offering. (lines 2181-2183)

The verse then describes the Buddha's acceptance and teaching:

"The Buddha, knowing that the time had not yet come,
Accepted their request and sat silently,
And the ten directions' Brahmā-kings,
All scattered flowers and made offerings,
Requesting that the dharma-wheel be turned. (lines 2185-2187)
'The Tathāgata is difficult to encounter,
May you with great compassion
Open wide the gate of immortal nectar,
And turn the unsurpassed dharma-wheel!' (lines 2189-2190)

The verse then describes the teaching of the four truths and dependent origination, and its vast effects:

"In the first teaching of the dharma,
Six hundred million billion multitudes
Exhausted the limits of suffering,
All becoming arhats. (lines 2195-2196)
In the second and third teachings,
Thousand-million Gangetic-sands of multitudes,
For all dharmas ungrasped,
Attained arhatship likewise. (lines 2197-2198)
From that point onward, those liberated
Were countless and incalculable,
Beyond all numbers in billions of kalpas." (lines 2199-2200)

The verse then turns to the Bodhisattvas' teaching:

"The sixteen young princes,
Became monks as novices,
All together requesting the Buddha,
To proclaim the Great Vehicle teaching. (lines 2201-2202)
'The Buddha knows our deepest hearts,
The deeds of our past lives,
With countless causes and conditions,
And varied parables and explanations,
Teach us the dharma of the six perfections
And the wonders of supernatural powers. (lines 2205-2207)
'Distinguish and proclaim the true dharma,
The Bodhisattva-path truly practiced,
Speak the Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Dharma
In verses numberless as Gangetic sands.' (lines 2207-2208)

The verse then describes the meditation period and the Bodhisattvas' teaching:

"Then the Buddha spoke the dharma,
And entered a quiet chamber,
Dwelling alone in meditative absorption,
Sitting eight ten-thousand and four thousand kalpas. (lines 2209-2210)
The sixteen Bodhisattva-novices,
Knowing the Buddha had entered meditation,
Each ascended the dharma-seat,
And proclaimed the supreme Buddha-wisdom (lines 2211-2213)
To immeasurable billions of multitudes,
For eight ten-thousand and four thousand kalpas.
Each guided six hundred million billion
Gangetic-sands-numbered multitudes,
And caused them to generate
The aspiration for supreme enlightenment. (lines 2213-2216)
'Those beings heard the dharma then,
Through countless births ever following their teacher,
Receiving from him the dharma's teaching,
All had perfect understanding. (lines 2217-2218)
'These sixteen Bodhisattvas,
Now have all perfectly completed
The Buddha-path and the Buddha-way,
Now in ten directions (lines 2219-2220)
'Each present in their Buddha-lands,
Each guides measureless billions
Of Bodhisattvas and śrāvakas.
That Buddha has now become known
As Amitāyus of the western land.' (lines 2221-2223)

The verse identifies Amitāyus (Amitābha) as one of the sixteen—a Buddha known across East Asia for his Pure Land teaching. The text thereby incorporates other Buddhist traditions into its vision.

The verse then arrives at the central parable's verses:

"As an example of skillful means,
There is a perilous and evil path,
Stretching and extending quite distant,
Beset with many poisonous creatures,
And devoid of water and plants—
A place all beings fear. (lines 2227-2229)
"Countless millions of multitudes,
Wish to pass through this treacherous path,
Their route extends five hundred yojanas,
And at this time there is a guide,
Wise and knowing, with excellent wisdom,
Known to navigate the dangers and to guide through." (lines 2231-2233)
"The multitudes became weary,
And spoke to the guide saying:
'We are now utterly exhausted,
And desire to return from this way.' (lines 2233-2235)
"The guide conceived skillful means,
And thought to employ supernatural powers,
Creating a great city,
With buildings adorned and fine,
With gardens and lotus ponds,
And parks filled with living things. (lines 2237-2239)
"With gates and high towers,
And male and female inhabitants. (lines 2240-2241)
"The guide then spoke to the multitudes:
'Do not fear or turn back,
This great city you may enter,
And do as you please.' (lines 2241-2243)
"The exhausted multitudes,
Hearing of the city,
Became greatly delighted,
And all felt at peace,
Thinking they had been freed
From the treacherous path,
And had gained safe rest.' (lines 2243-2245)
"The guide then knew the people
Had rested and were no longer weary,
And assembled the multitudes to say:
'Go forward, travelers!
The treasure is nearby.
This city I created
As a resting place,
Recognizing your fatigue,
I used skillful powers—
The city you saw is not real,
But created by me. (lines 2245-2250)
'Now press forward together,
To the treasure place.' (lines 2249-2250)

The verse then applies the parable:

"I too am like this guide,
The guide for all beings.
Seeing that they seek the dharma,
Walking the middle path through dangerous realms,
Unable to endure the suffering of birth and death,
And these afflicted and fearful realms. (lines 2251-2253)
"I employed skillful means,
Teaching cessation as nirvana,
Proclaiming: 'Your suffering is extinct,
Your work is now complete.'
Once you knew you had reached nirvana,
All becoming arhats,
I then gathered the great multitude
And taught them the true dharma. (lines 2255-2259)
'The Buddhas' skillful means,
Distinguishing the three vehicles—
There is truly only one Buddha-vehicle,
Teaching the two vehicles as a resting place. (lines 2257-2259)
'Now for your sake I teach the real:
What you have achieved is not extinction. (lines 2259-2260)"

This verse section powerfully reiterates the parable's implications, showing the Buddha as guide, skillful means as compassionate pedagogy, and the three vehicles as provisional destinations within the One Buddha Vehicle.

---

## Summary: The Phantom City's Ultimate Meaning

Chapter 7 completes the doctrinal revolution begun in Chapter 2. If Chapter 2 established that skillful means exist, Chapter 7 now reveals their purpose and justification. The three vehicles are not different paths to different destinations but stages on a single path, with the phantom city representing the provisional achievement of nirvana.

This revelation requires complete reinterpretation of everything preceding it:

1. The Buddha's teaching of the three vehicles is not deceptive but compassionately adapted 2. The śrāvakas' nirvana is not final extinction but rest-and-refresh within the larger journey 3. The prophecies in Chapter 6 are not promises of future Buddhahood but recognitions of eternal truth 4. The present assembly consists of beings who have heard this dharma countless times across countless lifetimes 5. The Lotus Sutra itself is the final revelation of what was always taught

The parable accomplishes what previous teaching could not: it transforms intellectual understanding into emotional-intuitive recognition. Readers feel the weariness of the travelers, the joy of finding the city, the shock of learning it's illusory, and the gratitude for the guide's compassion.

This emotional-narrative pedagogy itself exemplifies skillful means: the Buddha uses the form that reaches hearts, not merely minds.

---

## Consequences and Implications

For understanding the three vehicles: They are not unequal or inferior paths but provisional destinations. A śrāvaka who practices well achieves real rest and benefit; it's just not the ultimate destination. For understanding the Buddha: The Buddha is revealed as guide (導師) rather than distant deity. The Buddha observes, knows conditions, adapts teaching, ensures beings advance according to capacity. For understanding enlightenment: It is not monopoly of rare individuals but destiny of all beings. Every being has encountered this teaching, rests in provisional achievements, and is guided toward ultimate awakening. For understanding the dharma: It is singular in taste yet infinite in expression. Like rain falling equally yet nourishing different plants differently, the dharma reaches all beings yet produces differentiated realization according to each being's nature. For understanding practice: It need not be harsh or extreme. The guide allows travelers to rest in the phantom city; rest is real and necessary. Only when rested can they continue. This compassionate recognition of beings' limits is itself the dharma.

---

10.title: Chapter 10: Dharma Teacher
verses: The Buddha now elaborates the prophecy and protection in extensive verse, emphasizing the supreme difficulty and supreme importance of dharma-teaching:
> "Whoever wishes to dwell in the Buddha-path > And accomplish naturally perfect wisdom, > Should constantly diligently make offerings > To those who uphold the Lotus Sutra.
> Whoever wishes to swiftly obtain > All-encompassing wisdom, > Should uphold this sutra > And make offerings to its keepers.
> Those able to uphold the Lotus Sutra, > Know that they are the Buddha's messengers, > Compassionate toward all beings.
> Those able to uphold the Lotus Sutra, > Abandon the pure realms, > Out of compassion for beings, taking birth here.
> Know that such persons > Are free to be reborn as they wish, > Able to proclaim the unsurpassed dharma > In this degenerate world.
> With celestial flowers and fragrances > And celestial jeweled clothes, > And celestial precious treasure-heaps, > Make offerings to the dharma-teachers." (lines 2553-2567)
The verse then expands the comparison through an elaborate system of merit-calculations, each attempting to measure the incomparable value of dharma-teaching:
> "If during one entire kalpa, > One harbored unwholesome heart, > Made angry expression and reviled the Buddha, > One would obtain immeasurable grave sin.
> But if one spoke even one evil word > To revile those who read, recite, and uphold > The Lotus Sutra, > One's sin would exceed that even more.

> > Evil spirits will enter their bodies > To revile and insult us. > We, revering and trusting the Buddha, > Shall don the armor of patience. > > For the sake of preaching this sūtra, > We shall endure these difficulties. > We cherish not our own lives, > But care only for the supreme Way. > > In the age to come > We shall protect what the Buddha entrusts. > May the World-Honored One himself know this: > The evil monks of the turbid age, > > Not knowing the Buddha's skillful means, > The teachings expounded according to circumstance, > Will speak harsh words with angry faces, > And repeatedly have us expelled, > > Driving us far from stupas and temples. > All such various evils— > Mindful of the Buddha's admonitions, > We shall endure all these things.¹⁴
## SCHOLARLY APPARATUS

¹: The pledge includes the phrase "in written form" (shu 書), establishing that dharma-transmission requires material preservation. The text is not merely oral teaching but written scripture that can survive the teacher's extinction. This principle explains the Lotus Sutra's own obsession with preserving itself—the text is self-aware that it is the mechanism of its own transmission. ²: The five hundred arhats' vow to teach in "different lands" (i guo tu 異國土) establishes that transmission is not geographically limited. The teaching spreads through space, just as it survives through time. The plural "lands" suggests both different physical regions and different mind-states or consciousness-realms. ³: The description of Sahā-world beings as "twisted in thought" (xin bu zhi cheng 心不實直) suggests that authenticity itself is what is lacking. In a world of pretense and dishonesty, teaching the truth becomes maximally difficult because the truth will be rejected as threatening existing delusions. ⁴: The eight thousand practitioners' explicit acknowledgment of the world's corruption and their voluntary undertaking to serve it models the Bodhisattva principle: choosing difficulty because difficulty is where help is most needed. This inverts the logic that would have enlightened beings retreat to pure lands, remaining instead in defiled worlds specifically to serve. ⁵: The Buddha's discernment of Mahāprajāpatī's unspoken concern demonstrates enlightened consciousness's transparent knowledge of others' hearts. The Buddha doesn't require speech to know intention. This capacity to read consciousness directly is itself a teaching: the Buddha's omniscience is not magical ability but transparent recognition of what is. ⁶: The prophecy grants Mahāprajāpatī Buddha before "six hundred and eighty billion Buddhas"—an incomprehensibly vast number. This temporal scope suggests that enlightenment isn't a onetime achievement but an eternally renewed becoming. The Buddha-realm is inexhaustible; new Buddhas continuously arise. Mahāprajāpatī's role as teacher across these eons establishes teaching as the primary activity of Bodhisattvas in motion toward Buddhahood. ⁷: Yaśodharā's unspoken anxiety triggers the Buddha's direct address. That even the wife of the Buddha (in his previous life as a prince) experiences concern about her future status demonstrates that no position—however exalted—guarantees recognition. This humbling of status establishes the teaching's genuine universality: all must receive the prophecy; none is assured beforehand. ⁸: Yaśodharā's prophecy specifies "a good and wholesome world-realm" (shan guo tu 善國土) rather than the Sahā world's defiled condition. This suggests that different Buddhas manifest in different world-conditions: some as teachers in pure lands (Yaśodharā), some as teachers in defiled worlds (the Bodhisattvas who vow to remain in Sahā). Both modes of service are honored. ⁹: The nuns' verse of celebration emphasizes that the prophecy brings "completion and full satisfaction" (xin an ju zu 心安具足). This suggests that prophecy fulfills an existential hunger: the need to know one's ultimate significance and destiny. Yet paradoxically, this assurance doesn't produce passivity but rather becomes motivation for immediate teaching. ¹⁰: The nuns' declaration to "teach extensively in other lands" echoes the Buddha's own previous declarations about dharma-transmission. The text creates a replication-pattern: the Buddha's vows to teach become the disciples' vows, which become their successors' vows, extending infinitely. The transmission is not a one-time transfer but perpetual replication of compassionate commitment. ¹¹: The "eighty million billions of countless Bodhisattvas" represents an immense assembly already present, waiting for their moment of vow-making. This suggests that enlightened commitment is always already present throughout the universe, awaiting only the occasion to manifest. The Buddha doesn't create commitment; he calls forth what eternally exists. ¹²: The two thoughts generated by the Bodhisattvas model the internal dialogue between obedience and autonomy. The Buddha's silence creates a gap that allows the Bodhisattvas to generate their own response from within, rather than mechanically following command. This gap is fertile precisely because it's not filled with coercion. ¹³: The phrase "all of this shall be accomplished through the power and grace of the Buddha" (jie shi fo li 皆是佛力) establishes that dharma-transmission, though requiring individual effort, is supported by cosmic power. The teacher's effort and Buddha's grace work together—not in opposition but in complementary fashion. This parallels modern systems-theory's recognition that complex systems require both internal agency and external support-structures. ¹⁴: The verse's repeated refrain—"we shall endure all accusations," "we shall not spare our bodies," "the Buddha understands our hearts"—creates an incantatory rhythm that itself teaches through aesthetic power. The verse is not merely describing commitment; through rhythm and repetition, it enacts commitment. Form and content align perfectly.

¹⁵: The concept of dharma as burden appears in the Sanskrit bhāra and in the Pali bhāra-formula of Buddhist practice. Rather than the teaching being a gift received with ease, it is a responsibility accepted with difficulty. This makes dharma-transmission different from commodity-exchange: it's not transferring something external but taking on the weight of authentic continuance.

¹⁶: Total commitment in Buddhist practice (samyak-sambuddha—perfect enlightenment—means "complete awakening") requires complete investment. The vow to "not spare bodies and lives" articulates this: there is no reserve remaining, no part of oneself withheld. This total vulnerability is what makes the teaching credible.

¹⁷: The description of the "dark age" (mo fa 末法) is a classical Buddhist concept of temporal decline. Yet rather than despair, the text responds by strengthening commitment precisely where conditions are weakest. This inverts the logic of decline: if transmission succeeds in the worst age, it's most powerful; if it survives the strongest opposition, its authenticity is proven.

¹⁸: Gender-inclusive transmission appears here as a natural consequence of enlightenment-recognition. Once the Nāga princess achieves Buddha-form and the other women receive prophecies, the equation changes: future ages will include female teachers teaching to both genders. This creates a genealogy of female dharma-transmission that becomes itself dharmic truth to be transmitted.

¹⁹: The Buddha's silence as supreme teaching accords with Zen/Chan Buddhism's principle of direct pointing rather than conceptual instruction. Words can mislead; silence invites authentic response. The Bodhisattvas' response emerging from silence is more genuine than response to explicit command would be.

²⁰: Autonomous morality (Kant) grounds obligation in reason's internal imperative, not external authority. The Buddhist version here substitutes wisdom's internal clarity for Kantian reason. The Bodhisattvas see clearly what the dharma requires and commit autonomously to it. This grounds commitment in wisdom rather than duty.

²¹: The lion's roar (simha-nāda) in Buddhist texts refers to the Buddha's and great practitioners' unafraid proclamation of truth. Unlike ordinary speech that may be tentative or self-protective, the lion's roar represents confidence grounded in perfect knowledge. The Bodhisattvas' vow, roared forth, is proclamation of ultimate truth.
